title: [Lecture Topic Task]: Maintenance Requirements (2.2.9)

labels.name: Task: lecture-topic
labels.description: Homework style task tied to lecture

body:
### üéØ Objective

Document and analyze the **Maintenance Requirements (Section 2.2.9)** for the *Pronunciation Coach* system, focusing on how the app will ensure long-term reliability, adaptability, and quality improvement through defined maintenance categories (Adaptive, Corrective, Perfective, and Preventive).

---

### üìù Description

This task involves reviewing and organizing all maintenance-related requirements that ensure the sustainability of the *Pronunciation Coach* system after deployment.
The maintenance section includes four key types:

* **Adaptive Maintenance:** Enables the app to evolve by adding new languages, supporting new OS versions, and maintaining accessibility compliance.
* **Corrective Maintenance:** Establishes a structured process for identifying, reporting, and fixing defects through crash reports, bug prioritization, and hotfix capabilities.
* **Perfective Maintenance:** Focuses on improving performance, UI/UX, gamification effectiveness, and pronunciation model accuracy based on real user analytics.
* **Preventive Maintenance:** Emphasizes proactive measures such as security scans, database migration testing, API monitoring, and code quality tracking.

Additionally, it defines a **Maintenance Process** that includes version control, documentation standards, resource allocation, and measurable success metrics (like Mean Time to Repair and Defect Recurrence Rate).
This ensures that the *Pronunciation Coach* system remains stable, scalable, and efficient as technology and user needs evolve.

---

### ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria

* Section **2.2.6 Maintenance Requirements** is fully developed and integrated into the documentation.
* Includes all four categories of maintenance (Adaptive, Corrective, Perfective, Preventive).
* Adds subsections for **Maintenance Process**, **Success Metrics**, and **Integration with Existing Requirements**.
* Each requirement includes clear purpose, rationale, and measurable targets.
* Aligns with software maintenance best practices and supports long-term sustainability of the app.

---

### üß™ Testing Plan

* Review that all maintenance categories are properly defined and formatted.
* Ensure that success metrics are measurable and logically connected to project objectives.
* Verify that the section links properly to related requirements (Sections 2.2.3‚Äì2.2.5 and 3.2).
* Conduct internal peer review to confirm clarity and consistency across subsections.

---

### ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe

Estimated completion time: **2‚Äì3 days**

---

### ‚ö° Urgency

- [ ] Low  
- [x] Medium  
- [ ] High  

---

- [x] Moderate  
- [ ] Hard

title: [Research] <Class Diagrams Object Model for Quiz Session, Persistence, and Prosody Evaluation>

labels.name: state: waiting for manager
labels.description: Waiting to be assigned / Waiting for Closing

body:
## üéØ Objective
Design a clear, maintainable object model (class diagrams) that covers quiz session state, per-word aggregates, persistence/sync, prosody evaluation results, and resource managers. The goal is a research spike that produces concrete class diagrams and integration notes that developers can follow.

---

## üìù Description
This task produces an object-level design that maps concepts in other artifacts (statecharts, Petri nets, algebraic merge operators, and prosody evaluation) into a set of class definitions and relationships. The deliverable should make it straightforward for developers to implement session flow, local persistence, offline merge logic, and prosody evaluator interfaces, and to connect these classes with other useful chart models.

Key points to cover:

Class structures for session management (Session, Question, Attempt, QuizSummary).

Aggregate and merge-related classes that implement algebraic merge operators (Aggregate, MergeOperator, EventIdSet/CompactDeduper).

Classes for prosody evaluation pipelines (AudioSample, ForcedAlignResult, PitchContour, StressDecision, IntonationDecision).

Persistence and sync components (LocalStore, SyncManager, UploadQueue, ExportWorker) and how they interact with the class model and Petri-net resource regions.

Clear interfaces and data contracts for the prosody evaluator so the frontend can call it from Dart/Flutter.

Mapping notes: for each class, show which statechart place or Petri-net place/transition it corresponds to and the lifecycle methods triggered by transitions.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
Class diagram(s) in an editable format

 For each class: name, main fields, important methods (signatures), and short responsibility note.

 Mapping table that links classes to statechart places and Petri-net places/transitions.

 Short rationale explaining choices for concurrency control (e.g., immutable aggregates, single-writer uploader, lock-free merge points) and recommended data structures for deduplication (event ID sets, bloom filters).

 Minimal Dart type sketches (interfaces / data classes) showing how frontend code can consume evaluator outputs.

 Risk and mitigation notes (e.g., large seen-event sets, GC/memory concerns on mobile, race windows between persist and sync).


---

## üß™ Testing Plan
 Review diagram correctness with other chart models (verify mapping table).

Walkthrough example flows using the diagrams:

Normal quiz: show class interactions from QuestionDisplayed ‚Üí Recording ‚Üí Evaluating ‚Üí Persisting ‚Üí ShowingSummary.

Offline + sync: simulate local events being folded into Aggregate, an offline merge with remote aggregates, and an upload via the UploadQueue. Verify the merge operator class behavior and that no data is double-counted.

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: 1 week  

---

## ‚ö° Urgency
- [ ] Low  
- [ ] Medium  
- [‚úÖ] High  

---

## üéöÔ∏è Difficulty
- [ ] Easy  
- [ ] Moderate  
- [‚úÖ] Hard  

---

body:
## üéØ Objective
Build and integrate a working **hierarchical state machine** (statechart) that directly controls the quiz flow at runtime replacing the current screen-based logic with structured, event-driven state transitions.

---

## üìù Description
Develop an **implementation** of a **functional state machine system** that manages the live quiz process through clearly defined states and transitions.  
The focus is on *execution and interaction*, not on theoretical modeling.  
The implementation should handle all quiz flow stages ‚Äî from waiting to start, through answering and evaluation, to displaying results ‚Äî while allowing nested (hierarchical) states and error handling.

This task demonstrates practical use of **statecharts** in code, showing how runtime state control can simplify flow logic and UI coordination.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `StateMachine` class implemented with support for nested (hierarchical) states  
- [ ] Quiz flow states defined (idle ‚Üí selecting ‚Üí answering ‚Üí evaluating ‚Üí results)  
- [ ] Event-driven transitions and guards working correctly  
- [ ] Integrated with quiz UI (buttons, progress, feedback)  
- [ ] Unit tests verifying transitions, entry/exit actions, and hierarchy behavior  

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
- Unit tests for transition logic and event handling  
- Integration tests confirming quiz state flow correctness  
- Manual UI checks of quiz progression and recovery from error states  
- Validation of nested state entry/exit consistency  

---

Estimated completion time: 1 week

title: [Feature] Implement Full ‚ÄúForgot Password‚Äù Flow

labels.name: task: development
labels.description: Dev work  Includes: code, design, testing, docs

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
## üéØ Objective
Implement a complete, secure, and user-friendly ‚ÄúForgot Password?‚Äù flow in the Pronunciation Coach app using the existing Supabase-based authentication stack, so that users who cannot remember their password can reliably recover access without instructor/admin intervention.

---

## üìù Description
This task adds full end-to-end password recovery to the existing auth system. The feature must integrate with the current Supabase Auth configuration used by the project.

When a user on the login screen taps ‚ÄúForgot password?‚Äù, they should be taken to a Reset Password Request screen where they can enter their email. Submitting the form will trigger Supabase‚Äôs resetPasswordForEmail (or equivalent SDK method) to send a secure reset link to the provided address, using a configured redirectTo URL pointing back into the Pronunciation Coach app. For security, the app must show a generic success message (‚ÄúIf an account exists for this email, a reset link has been sent‚Äù) and must not reveal whether the email is registered.

When the user opens the reset link from their email, they should be routed to a New Password screen (mobile/web route defined by the team) within Pronunciation Coach. This screen must allow the user to enter and confirm a new password. If the Supabase recovery session/token is valid, the app should call updateUser({ password: newPassword }) (or the appropriate SDK call) to update the password. On success, the user should see a confirmation and either be signed in or taken back to the login screen with a clear ‚ÄúPassword updated‚Äù message. If the link is invalid or expired, the app should show a friendly error and provide a way to request a new reset email.

The implementation should:
	‚Ä¢	Reuse the project‚Äôs existing architecture patterns (e.g., AuthRepository / service layer, navigation, theming).
	‚Ä¢	Follow good security and UX practices (no account enumeration, proper error handling, clear messaging).
	‚Ä¢	Align with the course‚Äôs expectations: requirements-backed, well-structured UI flow, robust integration with Supabase, and a verifiable behavior.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
	‚Ä¢	UI Entry Point: ‚ÄúForgot password?‚Äù link is visible and accessible on the login screen and navigates to a Reset Password Request screen.
	‚Ä¢	Request Screen: Screen includes an email input with basic validation and a ‚ÄúSend reset link‚Äù action.
	‚Ä¢	Reset Email Integration: Submitting a valid email calls Supabase‚Äôs password reset API with a configured redirectTo URL that points to the app‚Äôs reset-password route.
	‚Ä¢	No Account Enumeration: After submitting, the app always shows a generic success message without indicating whether the email exists.
	‚Ä¢	New Password Screen: A dedicated screen/route handles incoming reset links, allows ‚Äúnew password‚Äù + ‚Äúconfirm password‚Äù entry, and validates them locally.
	‚Ä¢	Password Update: With a valid recovery session, the app successfully updates the user‚Äôs password via Supabase and shows a clear success message.
	‚Ä¢	Error Handling: Invalid/expired token, network errors, and invalid inputs display user-friendly messages and safe recovery options (e.g., link to request reset again).
	‚Ä¢	Navigation: After successful reset, user is either logged in or returned to the login screen with a confirmation state; no dead-ends.
	‚Ä¢	Consistency & Accessibility: UI matches existing design, supports keyboard/screen-reader focus order, and uses clear language (e.g., no raw technical error codes).

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
‚Ä¢	Manual Testing
	‚Ä¢	Request reset with:
	‚Ä¢	A registered email ‚Üí confirm reset email received and generic success message shown.
	‚Ä¢	A non-registered email ‚Üí confirm same generic success message; no indication of account existence.
	‚Ä¢	Invalid email format ‚Üí inline validation error; no API call.
	‚Ä¢	Use a real reset link:
	‚Ä¢	Open link ‚Üí confirm it routes to New Password screen inside the app.
	‚Ä¢	Enter matching valid passwords ‚Üí confirm success message and ability to log in with new password.
‚Ä¢	Regression Checks:
	‚Ä¢	Verify existing login and signup flows still work as before.
	‚Ä¢	Verify ‚ÄúForgot password?‚Äù link and new screens do not break navigation on mobile/web targets.

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: 3 days.

---

## ‚ö° Urgency
- [ ] Low  
- [ ] Medium  
- [x] High  

---

## üéöÔ∏è Difficulty
- [ ] Easy  
- [x] Moderate  
- [ ] Hard

## üéØ Objective
Evaluate and compare multiple word sources (libraries/APIs) to power a ‚Äúrandom word‚Äù selector for the quiz, then recommend a stack that maximizes and compares coverage, quality, and offline reliability.

---

## üìù Description
multiple word banks will provide a cleaner pool of English words for the quiz‚Äôs random-word generator. This research will prototype and compare at least three distinct wordbanks.

The three to research:

wordfreq

frequency-ranked, easy to filter by commonness; offline after install.

NLTK words corpus

Quick take: large, offline corpus; may include rare/archaic forms; needs one-time download.

english-words

Quick take: huge plain-text lists, MIT; mixed quality and no frequencies; offline fallback.
    Python: read from packaged file.

    Dart: bundle as asset, or use the english_words package as the Dart analogue.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
List the conditions that must be met for this issue to be considered complete.  
- [x] Look into the pros and cons of the different libraries
- [x] Make sure the libraries are available in python or at least in dart 
- [x] Able to pull words at random

-Pull words from each library at random

title: [Lecture Topic Task]: Evaluating Alternative Speech-to-Text Designs through Quality Attribute Analysis

labels.name: Task: lecture-topic
labels.description: Homework style task tied to lecture

body:
## üéØ Objective
Analyze how two different Speech to Text  design options, Whisper and Vosk, affect software quality attributes such as accuracy, performance, usability, and verifiability in the Pronunciation Coach architecture. 
---

## üìù Description
The Pronunciation Coach system relies on STT modules to provide pronunciation feedback.
The two candidates, Whisper and Vosk, present distinct quality attribute profiles:

- Whisper - Higher accuracy, but more computationally expensive and slower.
- Vosk - Lower accuracy, but lightweight and fully offline.

The purpose of this task is as follows:

- Identify two or more quality attributes affected by the choice of STT engine (e.g., accuracy, performance, verifiability).

- Construct a comparison table summarizing how each alternative performs for each attribute.

- Create a simple architecture diagram showing the STT module within the system and where the trade-offs occur.

- Write a short discussion paragraph describing how the trade-offs relate to the system‚Äôs overall quality goals and non-functional requirements.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
List the conditions that must be met for this issue to be considered complete.  
- [ ] Includes a comparison table covering at least two quality attributes.
- [ ] Provides a diagram showing where the trade-offs occur in the architecture.
- [ ] Offers an objective evaluation describing the trade-offs and their relationship to system quality goals.
---

title: [Lecture Topic Task] <Non-Functional Requirements (NFRs) and System Quality Trade-offs>

labels.name: Task: lecture-topic
labels.description: Homework style task tied to lecture

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
## üéØ Objective
Define, analyze, and apply Non-Functional Requirements (NFRs) in software projects, focusing on how different quality attributes (performance, usability, security, availability, maintainability) interact and trade off during system design decisions.

---

## üìù Description
This lecture topic task explores how NFRs shape the architecture and behavior of a system. While functional requirements specify what the software does, NFRs determine how well it performs. Students will identify key NFR categories, describe measurable quality attributes, and analyze how improving one may negatively affect another. Examples include conflicts like performance vs. security or usability vs. reliability. The task connects concepts from the Requirements Engineering and Software Design lectures, using real-world cases such as an airline timetable or e-commerce platform to demonstrate how engineers balance system qualities under constraints.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria

- Define at least five main NFR categories (e.g., performance, usability, security, availability, maintainability).
- Provide one concrete example and measurable metric for each NFR.
- Create a trade-off matrix comparing at least three quality attributes.
- Include a short scenario (airline timetable, web app, etc.) showing a real design decision between conflicting NFRs.
- Explain how developers can evaluate and verify NFR satisfaction (tests, logs, metrics).

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
- Review examples for clarity and completeness of NFR definitions.
- Check that each NFR has measurable criteria and potential verification method.
- Validate trade-off reasoning using one sample system scenario.
- Peer-review deliverable for consistency with lecture materials (Requirements & Design).

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: 1/2 days

---

title: [Lecture Topic Task]: Conflict Detection and Resolution for Gamification Requirements

labels.name: Task: lecture-topic
labels.description: Homework style task tied to lecture

body:
## üéØ Objective
Apply Conflict Management principles from Chapter 3 (slides 6-14) to identify and resolve inconsistencies between competing requirements in the gamification system, specifically focusing on streak mechanics vs. user flexibility needs.

---

## üìù Description
This task focuses on Inconsistency Management, particularly detecting and resolving conflicts between stakeholder viewpoints. According to slide 8, conflicts occur when requirements cannot be satisfied together, either as:

- Strong Conflicts: Logically inconsistent statements that can never both be true
- Weak Conflicts (Divergence): Requirements that conflict only under specific boundary conditions

In Pronunciation Coach, we have identified potential conflicts between:

1. Motivation requirements (strict daily streaks keep users engaged)
2. Flexibility requirements (users need forgiveness for missed days)
3. Progress requirements (XP should reflect actual effort)

Key Lecture Concepts Applied:

- Conflict detection using overlapping statements (slide 10)
- Conflict resolution tactics (slide 13)
- Systematic conflict management process (slides 10-14)

Why This Matters:
Our persons show conflicting needs: Maria (commuter) needs flexibility for unpredictable schedules, while David (dedicated learner) wants strict accountability. These viewpoints create requirement conflicts that must be resolved before implementation.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
Part 1: Conflict Detection (slides 10-11)
- [ ] Identify at least 3 pairs of conflicting requirements from existing documentation (Section 2.2)
- [ ] Classify each conflict as Strong or Weak with clear boundary conditions
- [ ] Document which personas or stakeholder viewpoints are in conflict
- [ ] Create an Interaction Matrix showing overlaps and conflicts between requirements

Part 2: Conflict Analysis (slide 8-9)
- [ ] For each weak conflict, clearly state the boundary condition that triggers the conflict
- [ ] Document the root cause (stakeholder objectives, non-functional trade-offs, etc.)
- [ ] Identify which requirements have the most conflicts (conflict count analysis)

Part 3: Resolution Generation (slide 12-13)
- [ ] Generate at least 2 alternative resolutions for each conflict using resolution tactics:
- Avoid boundary condition
- Restore conflicting statements
- Weaken conflicting statements
- Drop lower-priority statements
- Specialize conflict source or target
- [ ] Document trade-offs for each proposed resolution

Part 4: Resolution Selection (slide 14)
- [ ] Select preferred resolution for each conflict based on:
- Contribution to critical NFRs (user retention, engagement)
- Impact on other conflicts/risks
- [ ] Document rationale for each selection
- [ ] Update Section 2.2 with resolved requirements

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
Validation with Persons
- Review each conflict with team to confirm it represents real stakeholder tension
- Map each conflict back to specific user stories from Section 2.2.1
- Verify boundary conditions are realistic (check with ESL students if possible)

Resolution Feasibility
- Confirm selected resolutions can be implemented within current architecture
- Verify resolutions don't create new conflicts
- Check if resolutions align with Section 2.2.4-2.2.5 interface/machine requirements

Documentation Completeness
- Ensure all conflicts are traceable to source requirements
- Verify interaction matrix correctly identifies overlaps
- Confirm new resolved requirements are added to Section 2.2

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: 3-4 hours

---

## ‚ö° Urgency
- [ ] Low  
- [X] Medium  
- [ ] High  

---

## üéöÔ∏è Difficulty
- [ ] Easy  
- [X] Moderate  
- [ ] Hard

body:
üéØ Objective

Create a simple, user-friendly Settings Page that allows users to manage app preferences such as theme, sound options, and language selection.

‚∏ª

üìù Description

We need to design and implement a basic Settings Screen for the Pronunciation Coach app.
The purpose of this screen is to give users control over their app experience and personalize their interaction with the app.

The settings page will include:
	‚Ä¢	Theme Toggle (Light/Dark Mode): Allows users to switch between light and dark appearance.
	‚Ä¢	Audio Preferences: Option to enable/disable pronunciation feedback sounds and adjust playback speed (e.g., 0.75x, 1x, 1.25x) etc.
	‚Ä¢	Language Selection: Dropdown or segmented control to choose app interface language (initially English and Spanish).
	‚Ä¢	Reset Progress: Button to clear saved pronunciation history and progress (with confirmation prompt).
	‚Ä¢	About Section: Displays app version and brief description.

## üéØ Objective
Expand section 2.1 ‚ÄúDomain Description‚Äù of Team 4‚Äôs documentation by adding a new subsection 2.1.7 the models how observable instances (phenomena) and abstractions (concepts) describe the quiz‚Äôs entities, functions, and behaviors referencing the lecture material on Phenomena and Concepts (phenomena-concepts.pdf). 

---

## üìù Description
According to the lecture material on Phenomena and Concepts (phenomena-concepts.pdf), a phenomenon is an observable, concrete instance that can be sensed or measured, while a concept is an abstraction or class that represents a set of related phenomena. This issue focuses on identifying and classifying the phenomena and concepts present in the quiz algorithm in the creation of a new subsection 2.1.7 "Phenomena and Concepts for Quiz Feature". The new subsection will identify and categorize the entities, functions, and events/behaviors that make up the quiz, describing how concrete, measurable elements (phenomena) relate to abstract structures (concepts).

The analysis will include:

- Entities: Concepts that carry data, such as Word, IPA, Syllables, OptionSet, and QuizState.
- Functions: Operations that act on those entities, such as Get_Word_IPA(word) or Generate_Evil_Words(word).
- Events and behaviors: Observable actions during quiz execution, such as WordRequested, OptionsGenerated, and OptionSelected.

title: [Lecture Topic Task]: Risk Analysis in Requirements Evaluation

labels.name: Task: lecture-topic
labels.description: Homework style task tied to lecture

body:
üéØ Objective

Analyze and document the¬†Risk Analysis¬†process within the Requirements Evaluation phase, focusing on how identifying, assessing, and mitigating risks ensures the stability and reliability of the Pronunciation Coach app. The goal is to understand how potential failures or challenges are anticipated early in the software development process.

üìù Description

This task focuses specifically on¬†Risk Analysis, one of the core components of requirements evaluation. Risk Analysis helps the development team predict possible problems that could affect either the¬†product¬†(what is being built) or the¬†process¬†(how it is being built).

The activity involves three main stages:

  1. Risk Identification¬†‚Äì Listing potential risks related to user interaction, system performance, and data integrity.

  2. Risk Assessment¬†‚Äì Evaluating the likelihood and impact of each risk, either qualitatively (High/Medium/Low) or quantitatively (numerical scales).

  3. Risk Control and Mitigation¬†‚Äì Defining strategies to minimize risk probability or its consequences.

This method supports better project planning, resource allocation, and long-term maintainability. In the context of Pronunciation Coach, risk analysis ensures that challenges such as incorrect pronunciation scoring, progress loss, or system latency are handled before deployment.

‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria

‚Ä¢ Document identifies at least¬†five potential risks¬†relevant to the Pronunciation Coach app.
‚Ä¢ Each risk includes its¬†type (product or process),¬†probability,¬†impact, and¬†proposed mitigation strategy.
‚Ä¢ Risks are presented in a clear and structured format (table or list).
‚Ä¢ Includes at least one example of a¬†quantitative or qualitative¬†risk evaluation method.
‚Ä¢ All examples directly relate to real system scenarios like pronunciation analysis, XP tracking, or streak saving.

‚öôÔ∏è Example Table: Risk Identification and Control

Risk Type | Description | Likelihood | Impact | Mitigation Strategy -- | -- | -- | -- | -- Product Risk | Speech recognition produces inaccurate results for certain accents | Medium | High | Train model with diverse datasets and include calibration phase Process Risk | Delay in daily challenge implementation | High | Medium | Reassign developer tasks and shorten iteration cycles Product Risk | XP or streak data lost due to app crash | Low | High | Add automatic local data backup after every update Product Risk | Feedback delay frustrates users | Medium | Medium | Optimize audio processing and use async UI updates Process Risk | Poor team coordination during integration | Medium | Medium | Use version control and weekly synchronization meetings

üß™ Testing Plan

‚Ä¢ Review if each identified risk has a clearly defined mitigation strategy.
‚Ä¢ Simulate potential product risks (e.g., test app without internet, corrupt data scenarios).
‚Ä¢ Ensure the qualitative scoring (H/M/L) aligns with realistic probabilities observed during testing.
‚Ä¢ Validate that control actions can be realistically implemented within current development resources.

‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe

Estimated completion time:¬†1 day

‚ö° Urgency

Medium

üéöÔ∏è Difficulty

Moderate

title: [Lecture Topic Task]: Risk Tree Analysis for Audio Feedback

labels.name: Task: lecture-topic
labels.description: Homework style task tied to lecture

body:
## üéØ Objective
Analyze and document potential failures in the Pronunciation Feedback Audio Processing Module using Risk Tree Analysis (Chapter 3, slides 21‚Äì22). The goal is to identify how different component-level failures can lead to the main system risk: ‚ÄúInaccurate Pronunciation Feedback Provided.‚Äù

This task deepens the general Risk Analysis process by applying it to a specific technical area, illustrating how structured failure decomposition supports early detection and mitigation of reliability issues within the Pronunciation Coach system.

---

## üìù Description
This activity applies Risk Tree Analysis to visualize and understand how multiple audio-related issues can combine to affect feedback accuracy. The diagram should represent hierarchical relationships among potential failure sources and show how they logically contribute to the main risk.

Steps:
- Define the root risk: "Inaccurate Pronunciation Feedback Provided."
- Identify intermediate nodes: Subsystems such as microphone capture, MFCC feature extraction, and native model comparison.
- Break down into leaf nodes: Specific, measurable failure events (e.g., microphone static, sampling rate mismatch, corrupted MFCC coefficients).
- Connect with logic gates (AND/OR): Indicate whether combinations of failures are required or if one alone is sufficient.

**Lecture Concepts Applied:**

- Risk Tree structure (slide 21)
- AND/OR failure nodes (slide 21)
- Leaf nodes vs decomposable nodes (slide 22)

Why This Matters:
The MFCC-based pronunciation system (mentioned in Section 2.1.5) depends on reliable audio capture and processing. Understanding failure combinations helps us prioritize which components need the most robust error handling.

**Deliverable:** A documented risk tree diagram showing:

- Root risk: "Inaccurate Pronunciation Feedback Provided"
- Component failures: microphone, MFCC algorithm, native models
- Logical relationships (AND/OR nodes)
- Leaf nodes representing basic failure events

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
-  [ ] Risk tree diagram created (draw.io, Mermaid, or hand-drawn + photo)
-  [ ] Root node clearly identifies main system risk
-  [ ] At least 3 levels of decomposition (root ‚Üí intermediate ‚Üí leaf nodes)
-  [ ] AND/OR logic nodes properly labeled
-  [ ] Minimum 8 leaf nodes identified (specific failure events)
-  [ ] Documentation added to Section 2.2 or Logbook

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
- Review with team to verify failure scenarios are realistic
- Cross-reference with existing requirements (Section 2.2.4-2.2.5)
- Validate against personas (Maria's bus scenario, David's practice sessions)

---

title: [Lecture Topic Task]: <Petri net models about quiz session flow and offline sync>

labels.name: Task: lecture-topic
labels.description: Homework style task tied to lecture

body:
## üéØ Objective
Study how Petri nets can model, analyze, and validate concurrent aspects of the quiz flow and offline sync/merge logic, and produce implementable artifacts (models, diagrams, simulation scripts, and integration notes) that help developers detect deadlocks, resource contention, and ensure liveness and boundedness in the app workflow.

---

## üìù Description
Using the Petri nets lecture as reference, investigate how Petri net models (place-transition nets or colored Petri nets, where appropriate) can represent:

The quiz session lifecycle and per-question interaction (display ‚Üí answer ‚Üí prompt ‚Üí recording ‚Üí evaluation ‚Üí persist ‚Üí next).

Concurrent/shared resources (microphone, network/upload queue, export worker) and how those resources are allocated.

Offline/online synchronization and merge operations (how concurrent syncs and merges interact).

Produce clear Petri net diagrams, a short primer linking lecture concepts to our system, and a small prototype or simulation (script or model file) that exercises typical concurrent scenarios (simultaneous uploads, interrupted recording, resume + merge).

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
Short primer (1 page) mapping Petri net concepts from the lecture to our app (places, transitions, tokens, firing rules, marking) and why those properties matter (deadlock, liveness, boundedness).

 Petri net diagrams:

A place-transition net for the quiz session flow (single session).

A net that models concurrent sync/merge processes and shared resources (microphone, network).

 A simulation/prototype (small script or model file for a Petri net tool) that can run scenarios and produce traces or reachability checks (examples: simulate two concurrent uploads, simulate crash-and-resume with merge). Include instructions to run it.

 Analysis notes showing findings for each model: possible deadlocks, resource contention, required capacity bounds (e.g., queue size), and recommended guards or redesigns to avoid issues.

 Deliverables packaged as editable files (diagram SVG or PNG, model/simulation file, and a short DOCX or Markdown report). 

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
Create scenario scripts or model inputs for the simulation: normal flow, concurrent uploads, recording while an upload is ongoing, crash during upload then resume and merge.

For each scenario, run the model and inspect markings and firing sequences to check:

No reachable deadlock states in normal operation.

Boundedness: no unbounded token growth (queue overflow) under expected load.

Liveness: critical transitions (e.g., persist, export) remain fireable under reasonable conditions.

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: 2 days / 1 week 

---

- [‚úÖ] High

body:
## üéØ Objective
Create a centralized, reusable Sound Effects Service to provide auditory feedback for user interactions across the entire Pronounciation Coach App.

---

## üìù Description
The application currently lacks auditory feedback, which is a key element for an engaging and responsive user experience. We need to implement a centralized Sound Effects Service to provide consistent audio feedback for user interactions across the entire Pronounciation Coach App.

This service must be designed for reusability and easy maintenance. Future developers should be able to add new sounds or update existing ones without refactoring application logic, by simply modifying a configuration file.

**Interactions requiring sound could include for now:**

- Correct/incorrect answer feedback
 
- Tapping any button or interactive element
 
- Pressing the record button
 
- App navigation (e.g., moving to a new screen)

_*As the app is developed further, developers could add more sound effects if needed_

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria

- A SoundService class is implemented with a simple API (e.g., play('success')).

- The service is instantiated once and accessible app-wide (e.g., via a context or service locator).

- All sound files are organized in a dedicated /assets/sounds/ directory.

- A configuration file (e.g., sounds.json) maps sound identifiers to their file paths.

- The service includes a method to pre-load critical sounds for immediate playback.

- Sound effects are successfully integrated for at least the following: correct answer, incorrect answer, button tap, and record button.

- The implementation is decoupled from UI components, allowing any part of the app to trigger sounds.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan

- **Unit Tests:** Verify that SoundService methods are called with correct parameters from mocked UI components.

- **Integration Testing:** Manually test each interaction (e.g., button press, correct answer) to ensure the correct sound plays without audio lag or console errors.

- **Extensibility Test:** Demonstrate adding a new sound effect by only adding a file to the assets and a new entry in the config file, without changing the SoundService code.

---

title: [Task] Dashboard data

labels.name: task: development
labels.description: Dev work  Includes: code, design, testing, docs

body:
## üéØ Objective
Collect all phonetic features from user and reference audio needed to populate the pronunciation dashboard.
Example: Extract phoneme-level duration, pitch, intensity, formants, and MFCCs for each audio sample.

---

## üìù Description
We need to gather and store phonetic data to enable the dashboard visualizations and rule-based feedback.
The task involves extracting features from both user audio and perfect reference audio (TTS or curated).

Features to collect per phoneme:
- Duration (start, end, duration)
- Pitch (mean_pitch, F0)
- Voiced ratio
- Intensity
- Formants (F1, F2, F3)
- MFCCs (mfcc_1 to mfcc_13)

Additional metadata for dashboard calculations:
- Total number of words and phonemes
- Average phoneme duration
- Audio-level stats: total duration, average pitch, average intensity

This data will be used for:
- Phoneme timeline visualization
- Pitch and intensity contours
- Formant plots for vowels
- Rule-based feedback highlighting pronunciation errors

body:
üéØ Objective

Produce and integrate a comprehensive AsciiDoc for the ‚ÄúEmail/Password Sign-Up ‚Üí Auth User + Profile (Supabase)‚Äù feature (#207 ). The doc must live in docs/, render correctly (GitHub + local preview), and serve as the single source of truth for architecture, configuration, SQL, app code touch-points, UX behavior, verification, troubleshooting, rollback, and references.

‚∏ª

üìù Description

Create a new file docs/feature-auth-signup-profiles.adoc containing:
	‚Ä¢	AsciiDoc header & structure: include :toc:, :sectnums:, :toclevels: 3, :revdate: {docdate}, and a code highlighter (e.g., :source-highlighter: highlight.js).
	‚Ä¢	Content:
	‚Ä¢	App config (env.dart) and --dart-define usage.
	‚Ä¢	Supabase initialization (Supabase.initialize) with a custom LocalStorage backed by flutter_secure_storage (Keychain/Keystore).
	‚Ä¢	Database: public.profiles table, RLS policies, trigger function, and idempotent trigger installation.
	‚Ä¢	UX behavior for confirm-email ON/OFF; duplicate sign-up handling (and optional Before User Created hook).
	‚Ä¢	Build & Run instructions, Verification (SQL + app), Troubleshooting, Rollback plan, PR checklist, Security notes.
	‚Ä¢	Integration:
	‚Ä¢	Commit the .adoc in docs/.

‚∏ª

‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
	‚Ä¢	docs/feature-auth-signup-profiles.adoc exists and renders correctly on GitHub and in VS Code preview.
	‚Ä¢	Repository paths and filenames in the doc match the project (e.g., app/lib/...).
	‚Ä¢	SQL sections are idempotent (safe to re-run; no unguarded destructive drops).
	‚Ä¢	Verification steps include SQL to confirm table, policies, and trigger; app smoke tests are listed.
	‚Ä¢	Troubleshooting and Rollback sections are present and accurate.
	‚Ä¢	Security notes explicitly state ‚Äúanon key only in client‚Äù and reliance on RLS.
	‚Ä¢	References section includes the working links above.

‚∏ª

üß™ Testing Plan
	‚Ä¢	Render/Preview:
	‚Ä¢	VS Code ‚Üí install ‚ÄúAsciiDoc‚Äù extension ‚Üí AsciiDoc: Open Preview to the Side.
	‚Ä¢	Content checks:
	‚Ä¢	Verify TOC anchors navigate to each section; all external links open.
	‚Ä¢	Confirm repo paths in snippets match the codebase.
	‚Ä¢	Run the Verification (SQL) queries in Supabase SQL Editor to ensure table/policies/trigger exist and names match.

‚∏ª

title: [Lecture Topic Task]: <Lecture Topic: Automating Project Documentation using AsciiDoc and GitHub Actions>

labels.name: task: development
labels.description: Dev work  Includes: code, design, testing, docs

body:
## üéØ Objective
Automate the generation of project documentation by converting .adoc files into .pdf files through a GitHub Actions workflow.

---

## üìù Description
We need to ensure that all documentation within the repository (project handbook, research topics, and team deliverables) is automatically built and versioned.
This will be achieved using an AsciiDoc-to-PDF CI pipeline configured via GitHub Actions.

The workflow detects any changes made to .adoc files in the docs/ directory and automatically:

Builds PDFs using the asciidoctor/docker-asciidoctor container.

Commits the generated PDFs back into the repository under docs/pdf/.

Ensures continuous documentation updates alongside code commits.

This feature enforces consistency, avoids outdated documentation, and aligns with DevOps principles of Documentation as Code.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
List the conditions that must be met for this issue to be considered complete.  
- [ ] Workflow triggers automatically on .adoc file changes.  
- [ ] PDFs are generated successfully using asciidoctor-pdf.
- [ ] Generated PDFs are committed to docs/pdf/ automatically.
- [ ] Workflow completes without permission or rebase conflicts.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
How will this be tested?  
- Push updates to an existing .adoc file under docs/ (e.g., docs/research/documents.adoc).
- Confirm that the workflow runs under Actions ‚Üí ‚ÄúBuild & Commit AsciiDoc PDFs‚Äù.
- Verify the new .pdf file appears in docs/pdf/.
- Check commit history for chore(docs): update generated PDFs.

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time:  2‚Äì3 hours

---

- [ ] Low  
- [ ] Medium  
- [ ] High

title: [Lecture Topic Task]: Agile Development and approaching is as a teamleader inside the team.

labels.name: Task: lecture-topic
labels.description: Homework style task tied to lecture

body:
## üéØ Objective
Enable a 3‚Äì6 person team to practice Agile inside an existing Agile system, with the team lead slicing work, assigning clear starter tasks, and helping teammates to open follow-up issues for incremental improvements.
---

## üìù Description
We‚Äôll establish a way for a small team to deliver within an already-running Agile program (e.g., GitHub). The team lead acts as servant-leader + splitter: translating big-picture task into bite-size tasks that are ‚Äúready to start,‚Äù then handing them out with a minimal starter scaffold. Teammates work on small parts, and when they realize they can further upgrade or optimize, they create new issues (labeled ‚ÄúFollow-up‚Äù) rather than expanding scope mid-sprint.

These tasks would be described / handed out / furthered talked about in team weekly meetings where the Team leader can discuss with his team about the tasks that have already been done and how to further improve them.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
List the conditions that must be met for this issue to be considered complete.  
- [x] Weekly meetings with team
- [x] Constantly discussing about what has been done in issues and how to further improve them
- [x] Team works on their own upgrades without needing to be 'hand-held' through out the course of the project and development

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
How will this be tested?  
-  Assign specific task to the team 
-  Putting tasks and issues together to form one cohesive program which works (In my team's case, that being the quiz)
-  Constantly check up on the team's progress

---

Estimated completion time: _e.g., Course of the project's lifespan.

## üéØ Objective
Establish and apply a repeatable method to detect, classify, and resolve requirements conflicts, and produce the Lecture Topic Task.

---

## üìù Description
I‚Äôve observed ambiguous and conflicting statements in the spec (e.g., mixed meanings of User, time windows expressed as points vs. intervals). In this task I will introduce a 5-step conflict workflow (overlaps ‚Üí detect ‚Üí document ‚Üí generate ‚Üí select) plus a propagation note, and compile the content into a polished PDF.

Scope (initial pass)
- Target features: Login, Quiz attempts, Feedback/Results.
- Conflict types to consider: terminology, designation, structure; weak vs. strong.

References: my class notes/slides for Requirements Evaluation and Design.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria

- A Conflict Log exists in the repo (e.g., docs/conflicts/CONFLICT_LOG.md) with at least 3 entries (CF-IDs).
- Each entry includes: statements, clash type, strength, boundary (for weak), ‚â•3 candidate resolutions, decision & rationale, impacted artifacts, verification.
-  The Glossary is updated with new/clarified terms (e.g., StudentUser, StaffUser, SessionDuration).
- At least 1 requirement is rewritten to remove a conflict (before/after shown in the PR).
- Verification hooks are added (at least one unit/widget test or manual step linked in the PR).
- A mini slide deck (10‚Äì12 min) is committed under docs/lectures/ with agenda + examples.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan

- Review checklist: In the PR, I‚Äôll verify each CF-ID entry contains all required fields.
- Unit/Widget tests:
  - RB-READONLY-STUDENT (student cannot edit rubric).
  - RA-EDIT-STAFF (staff can edit rubric).
  - Boundary test for the feedback window (e.g., 15 minutes after submission).
- Manual walkthrough: I‚Äôll simulate the accommodation path and confirm the policy-based weakening is respected.
- CI checks: Markdown links are valid; glossary terms are cross-referenced.

body:
## üéØ Objective

Turn the existing Python TTS multiple-choice quiz into Dart (Flutter), keeping the same behavior and flow.

---

## üìù Description

Port the Python CLI quiz (with TTS and A‚ÄìD options) to a Dart/Flutter app. The current Python script:
Speaks a prompt: ‚ÄúChoose the correct way of saying <word>‚Äù
Generates 3 misspellings + 1 correct answer, shuffles, and reads all options A‚ÄìD in a single utterance
Prints only the letters A, B, C, D (no words) to the console
Repeats the same word (reshuffling options) until the user picks the correct one
Says ‚ÄúCorrect!‚Äù on success and ‚ÄúNext word.‚Äù before moving on. The Dart version should replicate this UX, using a TTS engine and simple UI to select A‚ÄìD. Keep config flags (e.g., repeat-until-correct, speech rate/volume, next-question cue) and the same wordlist behavior.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
List the conditions that must be met for this issue to be considered complete.  
- [x] App speaks: ‚ÄúChoose the correct way of saying <word>‚Äù and then reads ‚ÄúA. ‚Ä¶; B. ‚Ä¶; C. ‚Ä¶; D. ‚Ä¶‚Äù in one utterance
- [x] UI shows only A, B, C, D as tappable choices (no word text revealed)
- [x] 1 correct answer + 3 distractors generated and shuffled each attempt
- [x] On wrong pick: says ‚ÄúTry again.‚Äù and re-asks with reshuffled options for the same word
- [x] On correct pick: says ‚ÄúCorrect!‚Äù then ‚ÄúNext word.‚Äù before moving on
- [x] Configurable speech rate, volume, and optional TTS boost/repeats
- [x] Final score announced at the end (spoken + on-screen)

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
How will this be tested?  

-Unit tests for distractor generation (unique, not equal to original; 3 returned)
-Unit tests for shuffle and answer mapping (correct label resolves correctly)
-Widget tests: tapping A‚ÄìD updates state as expected; correct vs wrong flows
-Manual tests on at least one Android and one iOS device/emulator for TTS playback, pacing, and utterance completeness

---

Estimated completion time: _e.g., 1 day

## üéØ Objective
Due to a not direct and easy way for Python code to communicate with Dart code (and vice versa), a rewrite of the code, from Python to Dart, is needed as a backup in the case the currently being implemented solution, use FastAPI for them to interact with each other, is not ready in time, or any unforeseen issues arises.

---

## üìù Description
Due to how Python and Dart/Flutter works, making the UI (written in Dart) communicate with the quiz logic (written in Python) became a task with a higher difficulty and learning curve. This is because Python and Dart/Flutter internally function differently and with a lack of accessible tools that help with the communication between them rewriting the code from Python to Dart is the best option, in terms of getting a prototype ready. A solution is being developed to make the programming languages communicate with each other, however it is uncertain whether it'll be ready in time. Because of this worry, this task serves as a backup solution.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Rewrite the quiz's code from Python to Dart
- [ ] The rewritten logic retains the same behavior with minimal compromises
- [ ] Due to it being written in Dart, UI compatibility is available

- UI input test (the quiz running with the UI as the frontend)

body:
## üéØ Objective
Build a small TTS-based multiple-choice listening quiz: given a target word (entered by the programmer for now), generate 3 vowel-swap wrong words, read out 4 options (A‚ÄìD), track wrong attempts, and move to the next word when the user selects the correct option.

---

## üìù Description
Create a command-line Python program that:
-Accepts a target word (manual input for now; word randomizer to be added later).
-Generates three incorrect variants by swapping vowels (configurable set: aeiou or aeiouy).
-Shuffles the 4 options (1 correct + 3 wrongly written) and reads them via TTS (pyttsx3).
-Prompts the user to choose A/B/C/D; counts incorrect attempts per word; repeats the same four options until correct.
-On a correct choice, announces ‚ÄúCorrect!‚Äù, records stats, and proceeds to the next word.
-Prints a brief, minimal UI (letters and prompts). Option to hide the printed words while still speaking them.
-Future scope (not in this issue): word randomizer, IPA integration, GUI.
---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
List the conditions that must be met for this issue to be considered complete.  
- [x] Given any input word, the program produces exactly 3 vowel-swap distractors (no duplicates of the correct word).
- [x] The four choices are randomly ordered each attempt and spoken in a single readout (A‚ÄìD).
- [x] User can answer with A/B/C/D (case-insensitive); invalid input re-prompts without crashing.
- [x] Incorrect attempts are counted and displayed upon getting the correct answer.
- [x] Program repeats the same question (same 4 options) until the correct answer is chosen.
- [x] On correct, program says ‚ÄúCorrect!‚Äù and then advances to the next word.
- [x] Config flag to include/exclude ‚Äòy‚Äô as a vowel.


---

## üß™ Testing Plan
How will this be tested?  

-make_distractors(word): returns 3 unique vowel-swapped strings, none equal to word.
-assemble_options(word, distractors): returns 4 options with exactly one correct.
-Input validator accepts only A/B/C/D; rejects others and re-prompts.

Manual test.

-Try words with repeated vowels (e.g., ‚Äúcooperate‚Äù).
-Toggle include_y and verify behavior.
-Simulate TTS not installed: verify text-only fallback.
-Confirm incorrect count increments and resets on next word.

Usability
-Verify the spoken prompt is clear and not clipped; A‚ÄìD are read in one utterance.

---

Estimated completion time: _e.g., 3 days / 1 week_

- [x] High

## üéØ Objective
Creating a secure and reliable token system that automatically refreshes the Supabase session, handles token expiration and tries to maintain the session in a secure state.

---

## üìù Description
While Supabase handles session refresh automatically. The app still needs a way to securely store and restore these sessions in the flutter app. Users shouls remain authenticated if their session is valid and automatically logged out or re-authenticated if their token is invalid or expires. This involves:
- Storing and managing tokens securely with flutter
- Detecting expired and invalid tokens and logging out the user
- Create a secure experience for the user

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Automatic token refresh will be implemented using Supabase
- [ ] Detect expired or invalid tokens and make the user reauthenticate or log out
- [ ] The session state should remain open and secure across app restarts

- Test the token refresh logic with Supabase sessions

- Confirm user is logged out when the refresh fails.

body:
## üéØ Objective
First, implement a function named Get_Random_English_Word() (or an equivalent) which contains the code where it extracts a word from an English Dictionary (Python Library) and returns it as a string.
Second, update the quiz where instead of the user inputting the amount of words and what words they'd like to practice, it automatically starts the quiz with a word selected by the previously mentioned function.
Lastly, change how the answers are generated with the purpose of making it compatible with the Text-to-Speech (being developed in #161)

---

## üìù Description
It's required for the function to grab any word from the provided English Dictionary to be used by the quiz and TTS.

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
List the conditions that must be met for this issue to be considered complete.  
- [ ] The function is capable of drawing a random word from the provided English Dictionary
- [ ] The function is able to return a string of the selected word for it to be able to be used by other components (e.g. creating erroneous answers, to be used by the TTS)
- [ ] The quiz no longer requires the need for the user to input their own words to practice

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
How will this be tested?  
- After creating the function, over and over again generate words to see the stability of the function
- Use a WIP version of the TTS to verify if, at the very least, is able to detect a selected word

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe

body:
## üéØ Objective
Implement XP (Experience Points) and achievements display system in the user profile screen to visualize gamification progress and motivate continued learning. 

---

## üìù Description

The Pronunciation Coach app currently tracks XP points and daily streaks internally (as documented in Section 2.3.2 UserProgress Component), but doesn't display achievements or detailed XP progression to users in their profile itself. 

***Lecture Topic Connection:***
According to the "Phenomena and Concepts" lecture, entities can be atomic (carrying a single value) or composed (made of multiple parts).  Our current documentation identifies UserProgress as a composed entity containing:

- XP points (atomic - integer)
- Daily streak (atomic - integer)
- Achievements (composed - list of achievement statuses)

***Current Problem:***
While Section 2.3.2 documents the UserProgress component's internal structure, we lack visual representation of these entities in the user interface. The lecture emphasizes that understanding whether entities are atomic or composed helps design proper data structures - but users also need to see these structures represented visually.

***Proposed Solution:***
Add to profile screen:

1. Atomic entities displayed individually:

- Total XP as a prominent number
- Current streak counter
- Individual achievement unlock status

2. Composed entities shown as structured groups:

- Achievement collection showing multiple achievement entities together
- Progress bars demonstrating composition (partial progress toward total)

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Profile screen displays total XP (atomic) and current streak (atomic)
- [ ] At least 5 achievement badges implemented with unlock conditions
- [ ] Achievement cards show: icon, title, and unlock status (locked/unlocked)
- [ ] Locked achievements show progress toward unlock (e.g., "7/30 days")
- [ ]  Unlocked achievements show earned date/timestamp

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
- Verify total XP displays correctly (matches earned points)
- Complete daily challenge and verify XP updates in profile
- Close and reopen app, verify XP and achievements persist

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: 3 days  

---

title: [Task] <Algebraic data merging and conflict resolution for offline quiz progress tracking>
body:
## üéØ Objective
Research and design a mathematically consistent method for merging quiz progress data collected while offline. Use algebraic reasoning to ensure that when data is synchronized, merges are deterministic, associative, and idempotent.

---

## üìù Description
As the pronunciation coach app grows, users may complete quizzes offline. When they reconnect, the app must merge local and remote progress records without losing data or double-counting attempts.
This research task explores how to model those progress merges algebraically, ensuring predictability and correctness even under concurrency or intermittent connectivity.

The investigation should explain:

-How algebraic laws (associativity, identity, commutativity, idempotence) can guarantee deterministic merges.

-How to represent user progress as algebraic aggregates (e.g., using Algebras).

-What known conflict-free replicated data types (CRDTs) or functional approaches could be applied or simplified for this context.

-A minimal prototype merge operator in Python or Dart that demonstrates the algebraic rules in practice.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
  -Clear explanation of how algebraic structures (monoid, algebras) can be used to define deterministic merge and identity operations.

 -Comparative overview of at least two strategies for conflict resolution (e.g., last-write-wins vs. algebraic merge).

 -Prototype merge implementation (in Python or Dart) demonstrating associativity and idempotence.

 -Unit-test plan showing how to verify algebraic properties.

 -Notes on feasibility and integration into the existing tracking system.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
Build synthetic ‚Äúoffline vs. online‚Äù test datasets that simulate delayed uploads or concurrent edits.

Apply the merge operator in different orders to confirm deterministic outcomes.

Manual review of merge correctness for human-interpretable fields (e.g., total score, per-word attempts).

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: 3 days  

---

- [‚úÖ] Medium  
- [ ] High  

---

# üéØ Objective
Set up an environment configuration template so all developers can provide their own API keys and build the project successfully.

---

## üìù Description
Currently, the project fails to build for users that dont have supabase setup because `lib/core/config/env.dart` is missing. This file contains critical environment variables (like Supabase URL and Anon Key) needed by `supabase_client.dart`.

We need to provide a **template** and clear instructions so developers can create their own local configuration, avoiding build errors while keeping secrets out of GitHub.

**Tasks:**
- Create `lib/core/config/env.example.dart` with placeholders for environment variables.  
- Update `.gitignore` to exclude `env.dart`.  
- Update `supabase_client.dart` to use `Env` for configuration.  
- Add a `README.md` in the `config` folder explaining how to set up `env.dart`.

- [ ] Developers can build the project locally after creating their own `env.dart`.

body:
## üéØ Objective
Create a rule-based system that interprets extracted acoustic features and identifies the type of pronunciation error, producing structured feedback ready for the NLP model.

---

## üìù Description
This module will analyze the acoustic features of each problematic phoneme (from the extraction module) and apply phonetic rules to identify what went wrong.

Examples:

- Duration Rule: If phoneme duration < 70% of native average ‚Üí ‚Äútoo short‚Äù
- Pitch Rule: Flat or abnormally high F0 ‚Üí ‚Äúintonation off‚Äù
- Formant Rule: Distance between F1‚ÄìF2 and native reference > threshold ‚Üí ‚Äúvowel distortion‚Äù
- Energy Rule: Low energy + low GOP ‚Üí ‚Äúphoneme omitted‚Äù
- Spectral Rule: MFCC distance indicates substitution ‚Üí ‚Äúsounds like /t/ instead of /Œ∏/‚Äù

The output will be a structured JSON, e.g.:
`{
  "phoneme": "Œ∏",
  "issue": "substitution",
  "note": "sounds like /t/"
}`
---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Accepts acoustic feature data per phoneme.
- [ ] Applies rule-based logic to classify errors.
- [ ] Outputs standardized JSON feedback.
- [ ] Includes basic thresholds for duration, pitch, and MFCC distance.
- [ ] Easily extendable for future rules.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
- Test with synthetic and real mispronunciations.
- Validate rules by comparing outputs with expected human feedback.
- Check edge cases (silence, overlapping phonemes).
- Ensure all rules log confidence scores or thresholds used.

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: _1 week

## üéØ Objective
Implement a Python module that extracts detailed acoustic features for phoneme segments identified as problematic by the GOP analysis.

---

## üìù Description
After running GOP, we will have a list of phonemes with low scores and their timestamps.
Using these timestamps, we need to extract relevant acoustic features for each phoneme segment.
This data will later feed the rule-based analysis module.

Features to extract:

- Duration (from alignment timestamps)
- Pitch (F0) ‚Äì using parselmouth or librosa
- Energy (RMS) ‚Äì overall loudness
- Formants (F1, F2, F3) ‚Äì especially for vowels
- MFCCs ‚Äì spectral representation of phoneme quality

The extraction process will output a feature dictionary or JSON per phoneme, including normalization if possible.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Module receives audio file and phoneme time intervals (from MFA).
- [ ] Successfully extracts pitch, energy, formants, MFCCs, and duration.
- [ ] Outputs structured JSON or Pandas DataFrame for each phoneme.
- [ ] Supports batch processing of multiple phonemes per audio.
- [ ] Can integrate easily with GOP results.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
- Use a short test sentence aligned via MFA.
- Manually verify extracted features in Praat.  
- Compare pitch and formant curves for correctness.
- Ensure feature extraction speed is acceptable (<1s per phoneme).

## üéØ Objective
Design and implement the acoustic analysis pipeline that detects pronunciation errors, extracts relevant acoustic features, and produces structured phonetic feedback ready for the NLP feedback module.

---

## üìù Description
We will develop the core acoustic analysis module for the pronunciation coach system.
This pipeline will take aligned audio (via MFA) and perform three main steps:

1. GOP or MFCC analysis (Another issue) ‚Äì Identify mispronounced phonemes using Goodness of Pronunciation scores.
2. Feature extraction ‚Äì For the problematic phonemes, extract acoustic and prosodic features (duration, pitch, energy, formants, MFCCs).
3. Phonetic rules ‚Äì Apply rule-based logic to interpret errors and generate structured, interpretable feedback such as ‚Äúvowel too short‚Äù or ‚Äúconsonant substituted.‚Äù

The final output will be a JSON structure describing each phoneme‚Äôs detected issues, which will later be passed to the NLP team‚Äôs model for natural language feedback generation.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Extraction module provides clean, normalized acoustic feature data. 
- [ ] Phonetic rule module classifies basic pronunciation errors (e.g., short vowels, omitted phonemes).
- [ ] JSON output is consistent, structured, and ready for the NLP feedback system.
- [ ] The overall system runs modularly and can be tested independently.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
- Validate extracted features (compare duration/pitch with Praat).
- Verify rule logic by checking that known mispronunciations trigger correct rule outputs.
- Ensure the JSON structure integrates smoothly with the NLP team‚Äôs pipeline.

body:
## üéØ Objective
Goal: Produce an implementation-ready specification that applies abstract algebra concepts from the lecture material to the Quiz Progress Tracking and Report feature. Deliver a short primer on the algebra concepts, mapped design patterns for persistence/aggregation/merge logic, and a small PoC (Proof of Concept) that demonstrates the ideas.

---

## üìù Description
Use the Algebras lecture to produce a practical design and a short proof-of-concept showing how the lecture‚Äôs abstract algebra concepts help make persistence, aggregation, and merges deterministic and testable. Work to include:

A doc covering the lecture concepts: carrier sets, operations and closure, associativity, identity element, free monoid (event logs), and folding/interpretation. 

A mapping that shows how those lecture concepts apply to the quiz tracking system: event logs as free monoids, aggregates as algebraic values with merge and empty, and folding events into aggregates via a mapping. 

A developer spec (Python and Dart sketches) with function signatures and the algebraic laws to test (associativity and identity required).

A short Python PoC that implements aggregate, merge, empty, foldEvents, and unit checks for associativity and identity.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
Mapping document showing how lecture concepts map to event folding, aggregate merging, resume and export logic. 

 Interface spec with signatures (Python and Dart sketches) and the algebraic laws to test (associativity and identity).

 PoC Python script (‚â§ 300 lines) demonstrating foldEvents, merge, empty and unit assertions for associativity and identity.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
Unit tests in the PoC:
Associativity: merge(merge(a,b),c) == merge(a,merge(b,c)).
Identity: merge(a, empty()) == a == merge(empty(), a).
Fold/merge compatibility: foldEvents(events) == merge(foldEvents(chunk1), foldEvents(chunk2)).
Manual review: developer walkthrough of README and PoC.

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: 3-7 days

---

## ‚ö° Urgency
- [ ] Low  
- [ ] Medium

title: üß© [Lecture Topic Task]: Identify Domain Constraints

labels.name: Task: lecture-topic

labels.name: state: needs fix

body:
üéØ Objective

Apply Domain Engineering principles (SE-V3:8, SE-V3:11, SE-V3:16) to identify and describe the constraints that exist within the project‚Äôs problem domain.
These constraints define what cannot happen or what must always hold true in the real world the system models.

‚∏ª

üìù Description

This task focuses on documenting domain constraints ‚Äî the fixed rules or limitations of the environment that the software must respect.

Examples of domain constraints include:
	‚Ä¢	Legal or policy restrictions (e.g., ‚Äúuser data must remain private‚Äù)
	‚Ä¢	Physical limitations (e.g., ‚Äúa sensor can only capture up to 100 readings per second‚Äù)
	‚Ä¢	Logical or business rules (e.g., ‚Äúan event cannot start before the organizer confirms payment‚Äù)

The goal is to create a short, clear list of 5‚Äì7 domain constraints that shape how the system operates.

Add them as a bullet list or simple table in the documentation under a new subsection:

Section 2.X.X ‚Äì Domain Constraints

‚∏ª

‚öôÔ∏è Implementation Plan
	1.	Review existing domain and requirements documentation.
	2.	Identify explicit or implicit constraints that come from the problem space (not from implementation).
	3.	Write short, clear constraint statements (1 sentence each).
	4.	Commit the update to the documentation (AsciiDoc or Markdown).
	5.	Link the commit or PR to this issue for manager review.

‚∏ª

üî¨ Testing / Verification Plan
	‚Ä¢	Team lead verifies that all constraints logically describe real-world limitations of the domain.
	‚Ä¢	Manager confirms that constraints are consistent with project goals and requirements.

‚∏ª

‚úÖ Deliverables
	‚Ä¢	New section in team documentation titled ‚ÄúDomain Constraints‚Äù
	‚Ä¢	A concise list or table of 5‚Äì7 constraints clearly tied to the domain

‚è∞ Deadline

Within 5 days of issue creation (preferably early in the milestone).

‚∏ª

title: [Lecture Topic Task]: <Implement AI Feedback Loop using Automata and Machines (SE - V2:11)>

labels.name: Task: lecture-topic
labels.description: Homework style task tied to lecture

labels.name: task: development
labels.description: Dev work  Includes: code, design, testing, docs

body:
## üéØ Objective
Apply the **Automata and Machines (SE - V2:11)** lecture to formalize how the application's **AI feedback engine** processes recorder user speech, evaluates their pronunciation, and returns adaptive and accurate responses. 

The goal is to model this flow as a **Deterministic Finite Automation (DFA)** to improve testability, traceability, and error handling in the pronunciation quiz cycle. This task ensures that every state in the feedback process (recording, analyzing, evaluating, and responding) can be validated and reused for further architecture tasks. 

---

## üìù Description
The task consists of defining, modeling, and documenting the AI feedback cycle using automata concepts. 

**1. Conceptual Design**
- Model the feedback process as a DFA:
     >States: Idle, Listening, Processing, Feedback, Completed.
     >Inputs: Audio Input, AI Score, user acknowledgement, network status.
     >Outputs: Textual feedback, pronunciation score, transition triggers. 

- Define Transition Rules: what moves the automation from on state to another. 
- Handle error transitions (e.g., missing audio, API timeout ‚Üí revert to Idle).

     
**2. Implementation Sketch** 
- Write a **pseudo-class or UML snippet** for a **FeedbackStateMechine** (Dart/Python)
- Include an **onEvent(event)** method that defines the transitions. **(PDF)**

**3. Visualization**
- Create a **state diagram** (PlantUML, draw.io, or Lucidchart)
- Show transitions like:

     >Idle ‚Üí Listening ‚Üí Processing ‚Üí Feedback ‚Üí Completed ‚Üí Idle

**4. Research & Comparison**
- Briefly compare deterministic vs. nondeterministic automata in AI feedback contexts.
- Example: nondeterministic responses may arise from probabilistic AI scores; mitigate by defining acceptance thresholds.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria 
- [ ] DFA state diagram included in the research PDF 
- [ ] State table created with at least 5 states and transitions. 
- [ ] Each transition mapped to real Flutter functionality (Idle ‚Üí Listening = mic widget active).
- [ ]  Deterministic transitions confirmed (no undefined paths).
- [ ]  Automaton traceability included in test plan (test IDs per transition).
- [ ]  Lecture **SE - V2:11** is cited.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
**1. Unit Tests**
- Simulate events triggering transitions and assert expected next states.
- Mock AI API response to ensure ScoreReceived event transitions correctly.

**2. Integration Tests**
- Use Flutter‚Äôs integration_test package to test full cycles.
- Validate UI updates (feedback message and next question).

**3. Error Handling**
- Simulate timeout in Processing; verify return to Idle.
- Test invalid audio input (corrupted file).

**4. Traceability**
- Link test cases to Acceptance Criteria with IDs (e.g., AI-FSM-03).
     
---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: 2 - 3 Days

---

## ‚ö° Urgency
- [ ] Low  
- [ ] Medium  
- [ ] High  

---

## üéöÔ∏è Difficulty
- [ ] Easy  
- [ ] Moderate  
- [ ] Hard

title: [Feature/Task] Comparison script for MFA models

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
## üéØ Objective
Implement a script to automatically evaluate and compare multiple Montreal Forced Aligner (MFA) models using a gold-standard reference.

---

## üìù Description
We need a robust evaluation pipeline that measures how well different MFA acoustic models perform when aligning the same corpus.
The script should:

- Compare each model‚Äôs output against a manually verified gold standard (TextGrid files).
- Compute alignment accuracy, mean absolute error (MAE), and per-phoneme error statistics.
- Record and compare the time each model takes to align the corpus.
- Produce a final report summarizing which model performs best across all metrics.

This tool will allow us to quantitatively determine which model yields the most accurate phoneme alignment and serves as the best baseline for further adaptation or fine-tuning.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
List the conditions that must be met for this issue to be considered complete.  
- [ ] Script accepts multiple model folders and a gold-standard folder as input.
- [ ] Calculates alignment accuracy, MAE, and per-phoneme error distribution.
- [ ] Records and reports total runtime per model.
- [ ] Generates a final summary ranking models by accuracy and speed.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
- Run the script using four different MFA models on the same corpus.
- Verify that the generated alignments match expected structure (.TextGrid files).
- Check that the script detects missing or mismatched files gracefully.
- Compare numerical metrics and visual outputs (phoneme-level errors) for each model.
- Validate runtime measurements using time or system logs.

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: 3 days 

---

- [ ] Medium  
- [ ] High

body:
## üéØ Objective

Develop and validate a robust phoneme level pronunciation scoring backend using the Kaldi Goodness of Pronunciation (GOP) framework.  
This covers the full pipeline from environment setup to testing and evaluation forming a solid foundation.

---

## üìù Description
To provide pronunciation evaluation beyond binary correctness, our system will integrate the Kaldi ASR toolkit with the GOP algorithm.  
The project involves:

1. Setting up the Kaldi environment and dependencies  
2. Configuring and validating the GOP implementation  
3. Testing the scoring accuracy and stability with real and synthetic speech data  
4. Normalizing and integrating the resulting scores into our backend feedback pipeline

This work enables phoneme level confidence scoring (0 - 100 scale), which is essential for providing meaningful learner feedback in our pronunciation coaching system.

---

## üß© Sub Issues
- [#168] [Task] Set up Kaldi GOP environment and dependencies
  Establish a working Kaldi installation and verify basic GOP functionality.  
  (Foundation setup - includes model downloads and environment configuration)

- [#169] [Feature/Task] Test Kaldi GOP scoring implementation with our dataset
  Evaluate GOP scoring accuracy with human and AI audio samples, implement normalization, and produce comparison metrics.  
  (Validation and integration step)

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- Working Kaldi GOP environment successfully configured and documented  
- GOP scoring pipeline processes dataset audio end to end  
- Scores normalized to 0 - 100 range and integrated into feedback format  
- Testing report comparing GOP outputs against expected human/AI benchmarks  
- Documentation detailing setup, usage, and next steps for integration  

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
1. Run sample pronunciation data through GOP to confirm functionality  
2. Test both human and AI recordings, comparing score ranges and consistency  
3. Validate that GOP scores correlate with pronunciation quality  
4. Verify reproducibility and runtime stability across datasets  

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated total completion time:  3 - 4 days (1 days for setup, 2-3 days for testing and analysis)

---

- Define verification goals and scope.

body:
## üéØ Objective
Implement a sophisticated loading screen system using advanced software design patterns specifically for replacing CircularProgressIndicator across the application, starting with login_page.dart integration.

---

## üìù Description
Create a comprehensive loading system that integrates seamlessly with the existing login flow while providing a foundation for application-wide adoption:

**Core Design Patterns to Implement:**

**1. Strategy Pattern - Multiple loading behaviors:**

     - PulsatingWaveLoader: Wave-like animation matching our blue theme

     - ProgressStagesLoader: Multi-stage progress showing authentication steps
 
     - MorphingShapeLoader: Shape-transforming animation

     - TextTypingLoader: Animated typing effect with contextual messages

Important: We will also coordinate to use the existing `AppColors` from `colors.dart` and dynamic messaging from `AppTextStyles` and as a test our first use for the loading screens will be in `login_page.dart`


---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria

**1. Login Page Integration**

- Replace current `CircularProgressIndicator` with new loading system (only for Login Page for now)

- Maintain all existing form validation and authentication logic

- Support dynamic messages during login process

- Use existing color scheme from AppColors

- Preserve responsive design with Sizer

**2. Pattern Implementation**

- Strategy pattern with 4+ loading behaviors

- Factory pattern for easy loader creation and configuration

- Observer pattern for state coordination with existing Provider

- Decorator pattern for dynamic theming using AppColors

**3. Loading Variants & Features**

- PulsatingWaveLoader: Wave animation in primary blue theme

- ProgressStagesLoader: Multi-stage progress (Validating ‚Üí Authenticating ‚Üí Loading Profile)

- MorphingShapeLoader: Shape transitions with smooth animations

- TextTypingLoader: Typewriter effect with rotating messages

- Dynamic color theming using existing AppColors palette

- Configurable duration and animation curves

---

## üß™ Testing Plan

- Test loading displays during authentication process

- Verify loading disappears on successful login

- Test loading handles authentication errors gracefully

- Verify loading works with existing form validation

- Responsive behavior across different screen sizes

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: Approximately 3-4 days

---

## üéØ Objective
To design an intuitive and engaging way to get the user's voice as training data.

---

## üìù Description
If we want the voice cloning model to mimic the user's voice, we need a feature on the app to get the training data directly from the user. This feature should be optional, yet encouraged by the app, and should be engaging and not take too much time from the user. It should be optimized to gain enough data from the user to clone their voice perfectly, while also assuming that the user's pronunciation is not perfect. This issue is to provide a flowchart of the user experience when using the feature. Multiple methods will be suggested.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
Conditions that must be met.
- [ ] Provide flowcharts with different methods that could be implemented
- [ ] Compare each method, taking into consideration the amount of data needed.
- [ ] Talk about different possible scenarios for different users.
- [ ] Provide a final solution.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
How will this be tested?  
- Discussion with other team members to ensure we agree on which method(s) to use.

## üéØ Objective
Implement a feature to clone the user's voice when giving feedback. 

---

## üìù Description
To give accurate feedback to the user, we will implement a feature that will clone the user's voice using AI by collecting data samples given by the user. This will help the user hear the correct pronunciation of the words that need to be spoken in their own voice. This way it's much easier for the user to understand the way a word should be pronounced. 

What needs to be done:
- Test and implement AI model functionality in python
- Design an engaging way for the user to provide voice samples from which the AI will be trained.
- Implement feature using Python and Flutter. 

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
Conditions that must be met:
- [ ] AI voice cloning mimics the users voice with high precision.
- [ ] User can provide training audio through an optional, engaging system or feature in the app.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
How will this be tested?  
- AI model will be tested by comparing it's output to the tester's original voice to determine accuracy.
- Run the feature through the app to get an idea of the user's experience.
- Test the full system (AI and fully functioning feature) to see if we get enough training data from the app feature to accurately clone the AI
