body:
## üéØ Objective
Implement a local JSON Word Bank that stores words with their IPA transcription and syllables to allow the quiz to validate user input and generate answer options offline.

---

## üìù Description
The current quiz prototype only recognizes a small test set of words defined in test.json. When a user inputs a new word, the program can't retrieve the IPA or syllables, preventing the quiz from generating properly.

This issue's objective is to create a local word bank and an access layer module that retrieves IPA and syllable data for any input word. The initial implementation will be offline, using CMUdict data through the pronouncing library to generate the bank. The structure can later allow for expansion through APIs (ex. Free Dictionary API) for missing words like proper nouns or phrases.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria 
- [x] A wordbank.json file exists and contains at least 500 entries with ipa and syllables.
- [x] The data_access.py module can: Normalize user input (case-insensitive, remove punctuation and white spaces). Return IPA and syllables for a given word. Handle unknown words and edge-cases.
- [x] The quiz uses the access layer instead of hard-coded test words.
- [x] The algorithm works offline.
- [x] The quiz runs successfully utilizing the word bank.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan 
- Unit tests for normalization, get_ipa(), and get_syllables() using common, capitalized, and punctuated inputs. 
- Manual testing with the quiz.
- Confirm that quiz generation runs smoothly.
---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: 3 days

Says: ‚ÄúPick the correct pronunciation for: {word}‚Äù

body:
## üéØ Objective
Implement a Python-based quiz that reads aloud IPA pronunciations and speaks four multiple-choice options for a single target word (1 correct, 3 distractors). The options already exist; this work focuses on text-to-speech (TTS) output.

---

## üìù Description
We need a module that:

-Accepts a target word and its IPA transcription (e.g., /Ààs…îftÀåw…õr/) plus three incorrect IPA options.
-Reads aloud (TTS) the prompt
-Confirms correctness, repeats with re-shuffled options on wrong attempts (until correct)

proposed way to handle this: 

Language: Python 3.10+
TTS engine): pyttsx3 with eSpeak NG voice (better support for phoneme/IPA-like rendering).


## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
List the conditions that must be met for this issue to be considered complete.  
- [ ] The program speaks the instructions and each option, with clear ‚ÄúOption A/B/C/D‚Äù labels.
- [ ] Works offline on Windows/macOS/Linux using eSpeak NG (or documented fallback). 
- [ ] Supports at least a core subset of IPA (primary stress, secondary stress, common English vowels/consonants).
- [ ] Includes basic error handling (missing IPA, TTS not installed, empty options).

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
Unit tests

Validation: correct answer detection regardless of position.

IPA sanitizer: simple mappings render without raising errors.

TTS availability check (detect eSpeak NG; skip with warning if absent).

End-to-end flow: given a word + 3 distractors, script speaks options; simulated input selects answers; flow loops on wrong, exits on correct.

Listen for intelligibility of stress marks and common IPA vowels (/√¶ …™  ä …î …ô …ù/).
---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: _e.g., 1-3 days

body:
## üéØ Objective
Research how phenomena and concepts apply to the Pronunciation Coach app, focusing on how observable language-learning activities (speaking, feedback, correction) can be modeled as software abstractions.

---

## üìù Description
This research task explores how the ideas from the Phenomena and Concepts lecture slides Ôøºcan be applied to the Pronunciation Coach app domain.

Things to investigate: 

- Phenomena are observable, real-world events ‚Äî such as a learner speaking a phrase, the app recording the voice, or feedback being shown.
- Concepts are abstractions in the software ‚Äî such as User, SpeechSample, Feedback, and Score.

The goal is to create a report explaining how the app‚Äôs domain (language learning and pronunciation practice) can be structured through entities, functions, and events based on these distinctions. You‚Äôll also compare how similar ideas appear in Domain-Driven Design (DDD) and UML, where phenomena map to events/interactions and concepts map to entities and data models.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Identify and describe at least three phenomena in the Pronunciation Coach app (e.g., speaking, listening, correction).
- [ ] Identify and describe at least three concepts (e.g., User, Recording, Feedback).
- [ ] Classify domain elements into entities, functions, and events/behaviors.
- [ ] Include a short diagram or mapping showing how real-world actions (phenomena) correspond to software components (concepts).
- [ ] Summarize how this improves the clarity of your app‚Äôs design and documentation.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
- Peer review the report for conceptual accuracy.
- Ensure examples are specific to the Pronunciation Coach app.
- Validate that the mapping between real-world activities and code elements is consistent.

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: 4 hours

## üéØ Objective
Integrate the concept of Rigorous Reasoning (TLA+) into the Pronunciation Coach documentation to ensure that the app‚Äôs system behavior, user interactions, and state transitions are logically consistent and verifiable at a conceptual level ‚Äî before or beyond coding implementation.

---

## üìù Description
Lecture Connection:
The Rigorous Reasoning lecture introduced TLA+, a formal specification language for verifying that system behaviors satisfy their intended properties. TLA+ uses mathematical logic to define states, transitions, and invariants, ensuring the correctness of complex systems such as concurrent or distributed applications

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Documentation includes a short explanation of how TLA+ or rigorous reasoning concepts apply to Pronunciation Coach.

- Validate that the modeled system states align with the real behavior of the Flutter app.
- Review logical consistency between ‚Äústate‚Äù and ‚Äúnext state‚Äù in documentation.

labels.name: Task: lecture-topic

body:
**üéØ Objective**
Define a project-ready Definition of Ready (DoR) and Definition of Done (DoD) for the Authentication module, and write formal Acceptance Criteria (Given/When/Then) for its main stories (Sign In, Sign Up, Forgot Password, Remember Me, Validation). This task applies the Agile lecture and produces artifacts that the team can use to implement and validate PRs.

--

**üìù Description**
This task applies Agile lecture topics (INVEST, Acceptance Criteria, DoR/DoD) to standardize quality and verifiability for the Authentication module.

**Work to include**

1. Auth-specific DoR and DoD
- DoR: minimal conditions to start (clarity, dependencies, risks, preliminary test criteria).
- DoD: what must be true to close (tests pass, UI validations, error messages, CI green, evidence attached, docs updated).

2. Stories & Acceptance Criteria (G/W/T)
- Write 5‚Äì7 stories: Sign In, Sign Up, Forgot Password, Remember Me, Field Validations/Errors, optional Logout.
- Provide 3‚Äì5 acceptance criteria per story in Given/When/Then format, including edge cases.

3. Stories & Acceptance Criteria (G/W/T)
- Evaluate each story against INVEST and propose split/refactor if not Small/Testable.

4. Implementation readiness
- Specify how PRs will be validated (unit/integration/UI tests, screenshots/logs, CI checks).
- Map stories to existing backlog issues if available.

**Deliverables**
- docs/lecture_topics/agile-auth-dor-dod.md
- docs/lecture_topics/agile-auth-acceptance-criteria.md
Both must reference the Agile lecture.

--

**‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria**
- Auth-specific DoR/DoD that reviewers can enforce on PRs.
- 5‚Äì7 Auth stories with Given/When/Then criteria covering happy path and errors.
- INVEST table with at least one concrete refinement per story.
- PR validation guide (checks/evidence).
- Files placed under /docs/lecture_topics/ and citing the Agile lecture.

--

**üß™ Testing Plan**
- _Traceability_: each criterion maps to a test ID and an Agile concept (INVEST/Acceptance). 
- _Edge cases review_: at least one error/validation criterion per story. 
- _PR readiness_: simulate a PR checklist (analyze + test + screenshots/logs) to prove DoD is verifiable.

--

**‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe**
Estimated completion: 1‚Äì2 days.

--

- [ ] High

title: Researching Voice Cloning Methods for Personalized Feedback
body:
## üéØ Objective
Research and compare different voice cloning technologies that could be used to reproduce a user‚Äôs voice in our AI Pronunciation Coach for personalized feedback responses.

---

## üìù Description
Voice cloning allows our AI system to synthesize speech in a specific person‚Äôs voice. For our pronunciation coach, this could enable the app to generate feedback or corrected pronunciations using the learner‚Äôs own voice, making the experience more personal and engaging.

This research will:
- Identify open-source and commercial voice cloning tools.
- Compare their technical requirements, accuracy, and ease of integration.
- Determine which cloning method would best fit our current project

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] At least 2 voice cloning frameworks or APIs identified (open-source or paid).
- [ ] Comparison table with model type, input requirements, quality, and latency.
- [ ] Recommendation of one or two methods that could be further tested

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
- Review documentation and sample demos for each technology.
- Analyze their API or library integration options 
- Check whether they can generate short, realistic audio clips using cloned voices.

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time:  _1-2 days_  

---

## ‚ö° Urgency
- [ ] Low  
- [x] Medium  
- [ ] High  

---

## üéöÔ∏è Difficulty
- [ ] Easy  
- [x] Moderate  
- [ ] Hard  

---

Suggested developer: _@omar_cordero_

body:
## üéØ Objective
Create a functioning prototype of a word comparison algorithm made from scratch with no ai models

---

## üìù Description
Based on previously conducted research, create a prototype for a word comparison algorithm with scoring based on how similar one word is to another. The code will analyze every phoneme in a word and compare it with its respective phoneme in another word, then it will traverse a graph in order to find the correct phoneme, and based on the path the algorithm had to take, it will determine the score, and potentially be used to provide feedback on what needs to change.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
 
- [x] Has functional code which recieves two words, and outputs a score based on the similarities between them.


---

## üß™ Testing Plan
There will be 12 different test cases. controls which are the exact same word, two words that share nothing in common, two words that are similar, and two words which are the same except for added or removed sounds

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
1 day

title: [Lecture Topic Task] Sprint planning on the feedback module for Milestone #2

labels.name: Task: lecture-topic
labels.description: Homework style task tied to lecture

body:
## üéØ Objective
Plan and organize the upcoming sprint focused on the user feedback module (Team #2).
This sprint will coordinate all steps required for generating pronunciation feedback, from the audio input to the phoneme-level evaluation and final user insights.
It will also outline dependencies with other teams and integrate ideas for Milestone #3, ensuring compatibility and scalability across all components.

---

## üìù Description
This issue covers the sprint planning for the implementation of the feedback workflow.
The process includes multiple stages that together form the pronunciation analysis pipeline:

1. Speech-to-Text (STT):
Use Flutter dependencies to get the transcript from the user, when no reference text is provided by the user.

2. Phoneme Alignment (MFA):
Use the Montreal Forced Aligner to align the transcript and audio, producing time-aligned phonemes for further analysis.

3. Acoustic Analysis:
Extract acoustic features (e.g., MFCCs, pitch, energy) and compare them against native benchmarks to detect pronunciation deviations.

4. NLP Feedback Model:
Use the results from previous steps to generate human-readable, personalized feedback for the user ‚Äî highlighting strong phonemes and suggesting improvements.

The sprint will define the division of tasks, integration points, and expected outputs from each step, ensuring all parts communicate effectively for the final feedback feature.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Sprint planning completed and documented for Team 2.
- [ ] Clear task breakdown per stage (STT, MFA, Acoustic, NLP).
- [ ] Identified dependencies with other teams (data format, API endpoints, etc.).
- [ ] Established evaluation metrics (accuracy, processing time, quality of feedback).
- [ ] Timeline and milestones approved by the team.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
- Validate each module independently (unit testing per stage).
- Perform integration testing between stages to ensure smooth data flow.
- Conduct an end-to-end test using a sample audio ‚Üí ensure feedback is generated correctly.
- Evaluate timing and performance of the pipeline under realistic conditions.
---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: _e.g., 3 days / 1 week_  

---

## ‚ö° Urgency
- [ ] Low  
- [ ] Medium  
- [ ] High  

---

## üéöÔ∏è Difficulty

- [ ] Hard

labels.name: state: waiting for manager

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
**üéØ Objective**
Make the ‚ÄúSign In‚Äù button functional so users can log in with their email and password.
Once valid credentials are entered, the user should be navigated to the UserProgressDashboard.
If credentials are incorrect, display an error message and allow the user to try again.

**üìù Description**
Currently, the LoginPage UI exists but the buttons are non-functional.
This task will implement the login logic and connect the ‚ÄúSign In‚Äù button to a basic authentication system.

The system should:
- Validate that the email is in a correct format and the password is not empty.
- Disable the ‚ÄúSign In‚Äù button while the login request is processing.
- On successful authentication, navigate to the UserProgressDashboard.
- On invalid credentials, show an error message using a SnackBar or Dialog.

**‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria**
- The ‚ÄúSign In‚Äù button remains disabled until valid email and password are entered.
- Pressing ‚ÄúSign In‚Äù triggers authentication and disables the button during loading.
- On success, the user is redirected to UserProgressDashboard.
- On incorrect credentials, an error message appears and the user can retry.
- Simple unit tests exist for email validation and mock authentication.

**üß™ Testing Plan**
Manual testing:
- Enter valid credentials (test@demo.com / 123456) ‚Üí Expect navigation to dashboard.
- Enter invalid credentials ‚Üí Expect error message.
- Try pressing ‚ÄúSign In‚Äù multiple times quickly ‚Üí Only one request should trigger.

Unit testing:
- Test valid and invalid email patterns.
- Test success/failure from mock authentication service.

**‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe**
Estimated completion time: 6‚Äì8 hours.

**‚ö° Urgency**
High ‚Äî This feature enables the main login flow for the app.

**üéöÔ∏è Difficulty**
Moderate ‚Äî Requires form validation, async state handling, and navigation logic.

**üë®‚Äçüíª Recommended Assigned Developer**
@aryam-diaz ‚Äî currently working on the LoginPage branch and familiar with its structure.

title: [Lecture Topic Task]: Add New Section 3.2.1 "Validation Scenarios" for Team 4

labels.name: Task: lecture-topic
labels.description: Homework style task tied to lecture

body:
## üéØ Objective
Expand section 3.2 "Validation and Verification" of Team 4's documentation by adding concrete stakeholder validation scenarios, directly applying lecture concepts on validation. This issue will be referenced by the lecture material on the topic, including lecture notes and PDFs (Phases of Software Engineering) which covered verification ("are we doing it right?") and the verbal expansion on validation ("are we doing the right thing?").

---

## üìù Description
Validation requires involvement of stakeholders and works best through inspectable scenarios rather than abstract requirements. Our documentation already contains a ‚ÄúValidation and Verification‚Äù section, but it currently describes these concepts in general terms. This task adds 2‚Äì3 scenario-based walkthroughs to the documentation under a new section 3.2.1 "Validation Scenarios.‚Äù

Each scenario will include:

- The goal from the stakeholder's perspective.
- Preconditions for the scenario.
- Main flow (step-by-step interaction).
- Edge cases / alternative flows.
- Observable outcomes that can be judged by non-developers.
- Clear acceptance criteria.

By expanding this section, we will align more closely with the lecture‚Äôs emphasis on validation, provide documentation that stakeholders can use to review the system, and strengthen our milestone submissions with concrete examples of how requirements are tested in practice.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria 
- [x] New section "3.2.1 Validation Scenarios" is added in the Team 4 documentation. 
- [x] At least 2 validation scenarios are fully documented in the section 3.2.1 "Validation Scenarios.‚Äù
- [x] Scenarios clearly follow lecture material (stakeholder-focused, concrete, inspectable).
- [x] Each scenario includes goal, preconditions, flow, outcomes, and acceptance criteria.
- [x] Each scenario is phrased so a non-developer stakeholder could understand and review it without technical knowledge.
- [x] Acceptance criteria inside each scenario are measurable and objective.
---

## üß™ Testing Plan 
- At least one teammate poses as a stakeholder and reviews each scenario for clarity.
- Confirm that verification is still covered under testing (unit tests, model checking, etc.) while validation is explicitly represented with stakeholder scenarios, as described in class.
- Ensure scenarios are understandable without developer knowledge.
- Verify scenarios are consistent with existing requirements and features.
- Check that acceptance criteria are measurable and testable.

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: 3 days

---

## ‚ö° Urgency
- [ ] Low  
- [x] Medium  
- [ ] High  

---

## üéöÔ∏è Difficulty
- [ ] Easy  
- [x] Moderate  
- [ ] Hard  

---

## üéØ Objective

Goal: Create a proper, implementation-ready statechart diagram that models the internal logic flow of the Quiz Progress Tracking and Report feature. The statechart shall be based on the class lecture material (Statecharts PDF) and be detailed enough to implement the behavior later.

---

## üìù Description
This task applies the Statecharts lecture material to produce a complete statechart that governs the quiz progress tracking and reporting flow. Deliverables must include a clear diagram plus an implementation-ready specification.

Work to include:
Review the lecture PDF (Statecharts lecture notes) and apply the relevant concepts (hierarchical states, transitions, guards/conditions, entry/exit actions, history states, orthogonal regions) to the quiz progress domain. 

Produce a visual statechart diagram that models the full quiz progress tracking flow, including session lifecycle, per-question states, recording/evaluation states, summary/export flow, error handling, and any parallel regions needed (e.g., network state). The diagram should follow standard statechart notation taught in the lecture. 

Produce a developer specification (markdown) that enumerates: states, events, transitions, guards/conditions, entry/exit actions, and history semantics. This spec must map each element back to the lecture concepts so reviewers can verify correctness. 

Include implementation notes for Flutter/Dart: recommended state-machine library (or pattern), suggested file/module boundaries, and a short code sketch showing how to wire the statechart to UI events and persistence.

Provide small example scenarios (at least 3) traced through the statechart (e.g., normal session finish ‚Üí export success, interrupted session + resume, export failure + retry) so reviewers can follow behavior end-to-end.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
A visual statechart diagram representing the full quiz progress tracking logic. The diagram must be clear, use standard statechart notation, and be checked against lecture concepts. 

 A developer specification (MARKDOWN) that enumerates: top-level and nested states, events, transitions, guards, entry/exit actions, history semantics, and any orthogonal regions. Each item in the spec must include a 1‚Äì2 sentence rationale and link back to the lecture concept where appropriate. 

 At least three worked scenarios traced through the statechart (text traces showing the sequence of events and resulting states), including normal and edge cases (resume after interruption, export failure + retry, low STT confidence handling).

 Implementation notes for Flutter/Dart that recommend an approach (state-machine library or pattern), show a minimal wiring sketch (pseudo-code or short Dart snippet), and list which UI components / modules the statechart will control.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
Traceability check: each major state/transition must point back to a lecture concept (hierarchy, guard, entry/exit)  

Scenario walkthroughs: run through the three provided scenarios and verify that the state transitions and actions are correct and cover edge cases.

Implementation readiness check: The implementation notes and wiring sketch must be sufficient in order for the logic flow to be properly implemented in the actual code.

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time:  2-3 days

body:
## üéØ Objective  
Add Section 2.1.8 "Domain Phenomena vs. Concepts Classification" to distinguish between observable instances (phenomena) and abstract categories (concepts) in the pronunciation coaching domain.  

---

## üìù Description  
Our current domain notes mix instances with types (is "Learner" Ana or the abstract category of all learners?). This section will clarify that:  
- **Phenomena = specific, observable instances** (Ana‚Äôs attempt at 3:45 PM, file ana_recording.wav).  
- **Concepts = general types/classes** (PronunciationAttempt, AudioRecording).  

We will also classify entities as **atomic** (phoneme, score) or **composed** (word, feedback, attempt).  

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria  
- [ ] Section 2.1.8 created with at least 8 elements classified as phenomenon vs. concept  
- [ ] At least 6 entities labeled as atomic or composed (with components listed)  
- [ ] Examples are clear and drawn from pronunciation coaching domain  

---

## üìö Examples  
- **Learner** ‚Üí Ana (phenomenon), Learner (concept)  
- **PronunciationAttempt** ‚Üí Ana‚Äôs ‚Äúhello world‚Äù attempt (phenomenon), PronunciationAttempt (concept)  
- **Phoneme** ‚Üí /Œ∏/ in ‚Äúthink‚Äù (phenomenon), Phoneme (concept)  
- **Feedback** ‚Üí ‚ÄúYour th sound needs work‚Äù (phenomenon), PronunciationFeedback (concept)  
- **ProgressRecord** ‚Üí Ana‚Äôs 78% score on Jan 15 (phenomenon), ProgressRecord (concept)  
- **AudioRecording** ‚Üí ana_recording.wav (phenomenon), AudioRecording (concept)  

Atomic: Phoneme, Score  
Composed: Word, PronunciationAttempt, ProgressRecord, Feedback  

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe  
1‚Äì2 days

title: [Lecture Topic Task]: Implement Closed Operations for LearningPace Enum

labels.name: Task: lecture-topic
labels.description: Homework style task tied to lecture

body:
## üéØ Objective
Refactor LearningPace implementation to follow algebraic design principles, ensuring all operations are closed under the carrier set.

---

## üìù Description
Currently, the LearningPace enum and its associated operations don't follow algebraic design principles as described in the Software Engineering course materials (Algebras lecture).
**Background:** An algebra consists of:

- A carrier set (our LearningPace enum values)
- A finite set of operations that are closed (take elements from the set and return elements from the same set)

**Current Issues:**

- Operations are scattered across multiple files
- No explicit algebraic operations like next(), previous(), or default()
- setPace() modifies global state instead of working with pure values
- Missing self-contained operations that would make the type more maintainable

**References:**

- Lecture: Algebras (September 11, 2020) - Section "how do they relate to software engineering?"
- Key principle: "concepts and operations easier to understand if self-contained"

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria

-  [ ] LearningPace enum has a static defaultPace getter returning LearningPace.casual
-  [ ] next() method implemented (casual‚Üístandard‚Üíintensive‚Üíintensive)
-  [ ] previous() method implemented (casual‚Üícasual, standard‚Üícasual, intensive‚Üístandard)
-  [ ] minutes getter returns appropriate Int values (5, 15, 30)
-  [ ] Helper getters added: displayName, subtitle, icon
-  [ ] MyAppState uses algebraic operations (incrementPace(), decrementPace())
-  [ ] All operations maintain closure (stay within LearningPace set)
-  [ ] Code includes comments documenting the algebra structure
-  [ ] Existing functionality preserved (persistence, UI selection)

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
Unit Tests:

- Test next() boundary: intensive.next() == intensive
- Test previous() boundary: casual.previous() == casual
- Test defaultPace returns casual
- Test minutes returns correct values for each pace

Integration Tests:

- Verify incrementPace() cycles through paces correctly
- Verify decrementPace() cycles through paces correctly
- Verify persistence still works after refactor

Manual Testing:

- Test UI pace selection
- Test increment/decrement buttons (if added)
- Verify SharedPreferences still saves/loads correctly

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion 2 - 3 days  

---

## ‚ö° Urgency
- [ ] Low  
- [X] Medium  
- [ ] High  

---

## üéöÔ∏è Difficulty
- [ ] Easy  
- [X] Moderate  
- [ ] Hard

## üìù Description
**Lecture Connection:** The "Phenomena and Concepts" lecture explains the distinction between phenomena (observable, concrete instances that can be sensed or measured) and concepts (abstractions, classes, types). This distinction helps our team and the teams in general to avoid confusion between actual runtime instances and the classes/types that describe them.

**Current Gap:** Our domain description sometimes mixes specific instances with general types ‚Äî for example, "Language Learner" might refer to Maria (a phenomenon) or the learner category (a concept). Clarifying these distinctions will make our design and data structures more precise.

body:
## üéØ Objective
Revise Section 2.1 of Team 3 documentation to follow Triptych lecture principles - domain should describe "as-is" situation only, with no references to "the system."

---

## üìù Description
**Lecture Connection:** Applies "Phases of Software Engineering" Triptych lecture - specifically the Domain Description phase which must describe the current situation without referencing the system-to-be.

### What to Fix:
Our current Section 2.1.5 (Domain Functions) describes what "the system" does instead of what happens in the domain naturally. According to the lecture, domain functions should describe domain operations, not system operations.

**Example of what's wrong:**
```
assessPronunciation : PronunciationAttempt √ó PronunciationModel ‚Üí AccuracyScore
Description: Compares learner's pronunciation attempt against native speaker model...
```

This describes a system function. It should describe what happens in the domain (like a tutor evaluating a student).

### What to Do:
1. Rewrite Section 2.1.5 - change functions to describe domain activities (tutors, learners, practice sessions) not system operations
2. Add Section 2.1.7 - document one pronunciation practice behavior as a sequence of events and actions
3. Remove any "the system" references from all of Section 2.1

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Section 2.1.5 rewritten with domain functions (no "system" references)
- [ ] New Section 2.1.7 added with at least one behavior sequence
- [ ] Zero instances of "the system" in Section 2.1.1 through 2.1.7
- [ ] All changes highlighted in yellow in the document
- [ ] Includes note citing Triptych lecture at end of Section 2.1

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
- Search document for "the system" in Section 2.1 - should find zero
- Have peer review to catch any system-to-be references
- Manager verifies clear separation from Section 2.2 (Requirements)

## üìù Description

‚Ä¢	Integration with our workflow, including easy access for batch processing of audio files.


---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria

title: [Task] forced alignment + posterior probabilities (Speech scoring algorithm)
body:
## üéØ Objective

Research and design a pronunciation scoring method using Forced Alignment (MFA) and Posterior Probabilities to evaluate user speech accuracy.

---

## üìù Description

To go beyond binary correct/incorrect pronunciation detection, we need a way to measure the chances that a phoneme was produced correctly. This method uses the teams existing MFA backbone:

- MFA Forced Alignment: provides phoneme boundaries and timestamps.
- Posterior Probabilities : provides confidence per phoneme

Tasks:
- Research how MFA outputs can be paired with posterior probabilities.
- Identify whether probabilities can be extracted directly from MFA or if an additional ASR backend is needed.
- Define a scoring function (normalize probabilities into a usable scale, like 0‚Äì1 or 0‚Äì100.
- Document pros/cons of this method compared to simple phoneme mismatch detection.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Documentation on how to extract posterior probabilities in the MFA/ASR pipeline.
- [ ] A proposed scoring method for per-phoneme pronunciation evaluation.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan

- Extract posterior probabilities and compare scores for correctly vs incorrectly pronounced words.
- Evaluate if scores correlate with human judgment.

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe

Estimated completion time: 2‚Äì3 days

---

- [ ] Low

- [ ] High

title: [Task] <Quiz Progress tracking and Report (state machine)>

labels.name: state: needs fix
labels.description: the issue was not defined or needs fix

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
üéØ Objective
Goal: Implement session summary and per-word progress tracking state machine so learners and researchers can see performance (accuracy, attempts, common errors) after a quiz session and across sessions.

üìù Description

This task is a lightweight local analytics backend concept for the pronunciation-quiz flow. During a practice session the app will record events (word ID, timestamp, result, attempts, STT/confidence, hint used). At session end the UI will present a concise summary (overall accuracy, per-word accuracy, words needing practice, attempts distribution). The app will also persist aggregated per-word statistics across sessions so users can track progress over time, and the team can export session data as CSV for offline analysis.

Deliverables:
A Flutter session-summary screen and end-of-session flow.
A local storage schema for per-session and per-word aggregates (suggest sqflite or hive).
Exportable CSV of session results and per-word aggregates.
Unit tests and simple integration tests for metrics calculations.
Data / event examples (for developers):


‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
 End-of-session summary screen implemented in Flutter that shows: overall accuracy, total attempts, average STT confidence, and list of words needing practice (by lowest accuracy).

 Per-word aggregate data stored locally (fields include word_id, times_practiced, correct_count, total_attempts, last_practiced, avg_stt_confidence).

 Session-level raw events saved for each session (so exports can reproduce session timeline).

 Export feature that writes a CSV with session events and a separate CSV for per-word aggregates. Export must produce files accessible to the user (or QA) on the device.

 Unit tests that validate metric calculations (accuracy, attempt counts, aggregation).



üß™ Testing Plan

Unit tests for aggregator functions (given synthetic event lists, compute accuracy and aggregates).

Integration test: run a simulated session of 10 questions (mix correct/incorrect), verify stored session events and computed aggregates match expected values.

Manual QA: run a real session on device/emulator, open session summary, export CSV, and inspect that the CSV contains expected rows and columns and that per-word stats persist across app restarts.

Edge cases to test: multiple attempts per word, very low STT confidence (should be reflected), resumed sessions (partial sessions persisted), export on devices with limited storage, and empty-session behavior.


‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: 3 days / 1 week

‚ö° Urgency
 Low
Medium
[‚úÖ] High


üéöÔ∏è Difficulty
[ ] Easy  
[ ] Moderate  
[‚úÖ] Hard

## üéØ Objective

Implement scoring system for the quizzes that awards full points for first-try correct answers, half the points for second try, and no points for further attempts. This logic will be tested on backend, expecting the quiz result values in the terminal after.


---

## üìù Description
Display a score for each quiz based on user answers.

- Each quiz has 4 options (1 correct, 3 incorrect).
- User gets full points(1.0) if the correct pronunciation is selected on their first attempt.
- User can retry the same question one more time for half the points(0.5).
- On the third attempt forward User will get no points.
- The final score will displayed on a results screen, with the following score of each question and details about the quiz


---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Track word, attempts, and points 
- [ ] Show Result Screen with total score with the individual score of each question

This feature will be tested using different grade scenarios:

Manual testing:

- [ ] 5/5 first try = 100%
- [ ] 2 first try, 3 second try = 70%
- [ ] All questions 3 tries and more = 0%

title: [Task] Whisper AI results
body:
## üéØ Objective
Evaluate the performance of the Whisper speech recognition model and upload the results in a structured format, so we can directly compare it with other models under consideration.

---

## üìù Description
We want to benchmark the Whisper model against alternative ASR (Automatic Speech Recognition) systems by running it on a controlled dataset of approximately 100 audio samples. The decision will be base on:

- Accuracy (percentage of correct transcriptions, WER)
- Latency (time taken to transcribe each audio)
- Resource usage (space, CPU/GPU, memory)
- Once the evaluation is complete, we will upload the results (e.g., as a CSV file) containing all relevant metrics for each audio sample. This will allow us to visualize and compare performance across models in a standardized way.

## This issue ensures that we establish a clear baseline for Whisper's performance, which will guide future decisions regarding whether to integrate or replace it with other ASR solutions.

---

‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria

[] At least 100 audio samples tested across all implementations.

[] Output a csv file with all the necessary data we need to compare it with the others models.

---

üß™ Testing Plan
How will this be tested?

- Run the Whisper model on the prepared dataset of ~100 audio samples.
- Collect transcriptions and compare them against ground-truth transcripts using WER.
- Measure latency per file and record system resource consumption during processing.
- Store all results in a CSV file.
- Verify that the results are complete, accurate, and in the expected format for future comparison.

---

‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: 2 days

---

‚ö° Urgency

[] Low
[] Medium
[] High

---

üéöÔ∏è Difficulty

body:
## üéØ Objective
Build a rule-based word categorizer that returns a difficulty level (Easy / Intermediate / Hard) from a word‚Äôs phoneme sequence.

---

## üìù Description
Build a small Python module that categorizes a word‚Äôs difficulty from its phoneme sequence. On input, normalize the word, obtain phonemes via the existing splitter (phonemizer) to one alphabet (IPA or ARPABET), compute transparent features (rare-phoneme ratio, consonant clusters, syllables, stress/length heuristics), and map a weighted score to a level using config-driven thresholds. Return a simple, lightweight word profile and handle out-of-vocabulary cases. This algorithm will later be used to seed the word bank.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- [x] Uses one phoneme alphabet consistently and documents it.
- [x] Word profile at least includes word, phones, features, score, and level.
- [x] Features includes at least: rare phone ratio, cluster count, syllables, stress complexity, length penalty (constants configurable).
- [x] Scoring is a weighted sum with config-driven thresholds that maps to one of the three levels (Easy, Intermediate, Hard).
- [x] Handles edge-cases for out of vocabulary/unknown words.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
How will this be tested?  
- Manual input testing.
- Perform unit tests for mapping, normalization, feature presence, edge cases, etc.
- Perform property tests to ensure that the same input returns the same output.

---

Estimated completion time: 4 days

body:
## üéØ Objective

Takes a user-provided list of words. (This will be done in another task)
For each round, picks one word at random and shows 4 multiple-choice options (1 correct pronunciation, 3 incorrect).
Randomizes the answer order every time the question is shown.
If the user answers incorrectly, reshuffles and asks again until correct, then moves on to the next word.

---

## üìù Description
Create an interactive quiz flow that uses the dictionary-style written pronunciation for each word (e.g., ‚Äúsoft¬∑ware‚Äù / ‚Äú/Ààs√¥f(t)Àåwer/‚Äù).
The system should:
-For each question, randomly select one unused word from the pool.
-Generate four options: the correct pronunciation and three plausible distractors.
-Randomize option order on first display and on every retry after an incorrect answer (no option should stay in the same position twice in a row if possible).
-On a wrong answer, provide feedback and re-ask the same word with newly shuffled choices.
-On a correct answer, provide positive feedback and continue until all words are completed.
-Track progress (questions answered, retries, score)
-at the end, the quiz should display how many they got wrong, before getting the right answer for each word.
---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
List the conditions that must be met for this issue to be considered complete.  
- [ ] User can input a list of words to form the quiz pool.  
- [ ] For each question, the app randomly selects one word not yet answered correctly.
- [ ] Each question displays exactly 4 options: 1 correct pronunciation and 3 incorrect.
- [ ] If the user answers incorrectly, the same word is asked again with the options reshuffled.
- [ ] The correct option can appear in any position (1‚Äì4) across attempts.
- [ ] On correct, the quiz advances to another remaining word.
- [ ] The quiz ends only after all words have been answered correctly at least once.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
How will this be tested?  
- Manual dev input
- Use the same words and once it works with one word, try for other words
- Take a moc exam as if you where an user

---

title: [Research] Login UI Flow & Usability
body:
## üéØ Objective
Research and brainstorm the flow and usability aspects of the login screen (Inicio de Sesi√≥n), focusing on user journey, error handling, accessibility, and security from a UX perspective.

---

## üìù Description
We need to research and brainstorm how users experience the login process from the entry point to dashboard access. This includes mapping the user journey, defining error handling and recovery strategies, ensuring accessibility and inclusivity, and balancing usability with security features (e.g., ‚Äúremember me,‚Äù 2FA, lockouts). The goal is to provide insights that guide a smooth, accessible, and secure login flow in Flutter.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
Research Deliverables:
‚Ä¢	Define user journey (entry point ‚Üí login ‚Üí dashboard).
‚Ä¢	Brainstorm ideas to keep login accessible within 1‚Äì2 clicks with clear CTAs.
‚Ä¢	Document error handling & recovery (invalid login messages, forgot password, brute-force prevention).
‚Ä¢	Brainstorm inline guidance for reducing user frustration (e.g., Caps Lock warnings).
‚Ä¢	Document accessibility & inclusivity measures (keyboard navigation, screen reader labels, error announcements, password visibility toggle).
‚Ä¢	Brainstorm ideas for color/contrast accessibility.
‚Ä¢	Define security UX features (remember me, seamless 2FA, account lockouts, ‚Äútrust this device‚Äù).
‚Ä¢	Summarize findings into a single document with a balance of flow, accessibility, and security.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
Since this is a research/brainstorming issue, validation will be through review, not code testing:
‚Ä¢	Peer review of research findings.
‚Ä¢	Team feedback on user journey flow and accessibility strategies.
‚Ä¢	Cross-check with accessibility guidelines (WCAG).
‚Ä¢	Ensure security measures don‚Äôt compromise usability.

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: 1 week

title: [Research] Handling Out of Vocabulary (OOV) Words in MFA

labels.name: state: waiting for manager
labels.description: Waiting to be assigned / Waiting for Closing

body:
# üéØ Objective

To research and document how Out of Vocabulary (OOV) words can be handled in the Montreal Forced Aligner (MFA). The focus is on leveraging MFA‚Äôs built in Grapheme to Phoneme (G2P) system, exploring alternatives and recommending the most practical approach for English and Spanish.

---

# üìù Description

MFA relies on phonetic dictionaries to align text with audio. However, when OOV words appear (names, slang, uncommon words), MFA cannot align them unless phonetic transcriptions are generated. This issue will:

- Investigate how MFA‚Äôs built in G2P handles OOV words in English and Spanish.
- Summarize alternative approaches.
- Document why MFA‚Äôs integrated G2P is likely the most suitable choice for our project.
- Outline the process of generating pronunciations for OOV words and integrating them with MFA.

---

# ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria

- Provide documentation of how MFA manages OOV words with G2P.  
- Summarize at least 1‚Äì2 alternative tools and explain why MFA‚Äôs G2P is preferable.  
- Document the steps for generating pronunciations for new words (English + Spanish).  
- Identify potential issues (accuracy, accented characters, special symbols) and propose mitigations.  

---

# üß™ Research Plan

- Review MFA documentation and community discussions about G2P and OOV handling.  
- Collect examples of how OOV words are managed in English and Spanish.  
- Compare MFA‚Äôs built in G2P with alternatives at a conceptual level (ease of use, accuracy, integration).  
- Recommend the best solution (likely MFA G2P) and describe how it could be implemented in practice.  

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: 1‚Äì2 days.

---

## ‚ö° Urgency
- [ ] Low  
- [x] Medium  
- [ ] High  

---

- [ ] Easy  
- [x] Moderate  
- [ ] Hard

body:
## üéØ Objective
Evaluate and compare different Speech-to-Text (STT) implementations ‚Äî Whisper (OpenAI), Vosk, and Flutter-native libraries ‚Äî to determine which is best suited for our project.

---

## üìù Description
The team will prepare a set of ~30 unique test audios. Each implementation will process the same 100+ audio samples. We will measure and compare:
- Accuracy (percentage of correct transcriptions)
- Latency (time taken to transcribe each audio, max 5s per audio)
- Resource usage (space, CPU/GPU, memory)

Since our target includes mobile devices (with limited computational power), performance on lightweight hardware will be a critical factor.
Each developer will create a sub issue and will upload their results.

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] At least 100 audio samples tested across all implementations
- [ ] ‚â•90% accuracy on transcription results
- [ ] ‚â§5 seconds processing time per audio file
- [ ] Documented comparison of performance, accuracy, and storage requirements
 

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
- Collect ~30 audios per developer (diverse voices, lengths, pronunciations).
- Share and consolidate into a test set of 100+ audios.
- Run each implementation (Whisper, Vosk, Flutter STT) on the full set.
- Measure accuracy, time per audio, and resource usage.
- Summarize findings and recommend the best solution.


---

title: [Research] Forced Alignment Evaluation for Syllable Boundaries
body:
## üéØ Objective
Research and evaluate lightweight forced alignment options to determine which approach (or combination) gives reliable syllable/word timings for short words and phrases. Produce reproducible experiment artifacts and a recommendation (with tradeoffs) for the team to act on.

---

## üìù Description
Forced alignment finds where each word, syllable, or sound starts and ends in a recording using the transcript as a guide. This timing is essential: it tells us where to measure pitch and loudness for each syllable.

This research will:

- Compare a small set of aligners (quick, developer-friendly tool vs. higher-quality batch tool vs. lighter Python options).

- Produce reproducible scripts and a short analysis that shows the accuracy, runtime, and integration effort of each option.

- Recommend the best fit for our needs (e.g., server-batch for dataset prep + quick aligner for near-real-time research), and describe fallback strategies in plain language.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- Short comparison document (2‚Äì3 pages) describing 2‚Äì3 aligners, including: ease of setup, expected accuracy, typical runtime, and integration considerations (research perspective).

 - Short analysis (markdown) comparing timing differences (start/end deltas), and a small downstream check showing whether stress-detection decisions would change between aligners (simple metric + a few examples).

 - A clear, actionable recommendation: the preferred alignment approach to implement, with rationale and estimated effort.

 - A documented approach (simple heuristic) described with pseudo-code and recommended scenarios where it makes sense to use it.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
Evaluate tools that can be used to implement the idea:

- a quick, developer-friendly aligner (e.g., Gentle) for fast experiments;

- a higher-quality batch aligner (e.g., Montreal Forced Aligner) for reference;

- a lightweight Python option (e.g., Aeneas) as a lightweight baseline.

Tool comparisons:

- Compare timings: compute per-boundary absolute time differences (ms). Compare mean, median, and percent within 25 ms / 50 ms.

- Downstream check: for a subset (e.g., 50 clips), compute per-syllable mean F0 (fundamental frequency) using the different alignments and compare resulting stress labels (did the stressed-syllable index change?).

- Quality notes: cases where alignments fail (noisy audio, OOV words, very short clips) and note mitigation ideas.

- Deliverable package: scripts, alignment outputs, comparison report, and recommendation.


Suggested success heuristics for research:

- Quick aligner produces word boundary deltas with a mean ‚â§ ~30 ms vs the batch aligner (reference).

- Stress-label agreement ‚â• 90% when using quick aligner vs batch aligner for the subset.

- Scripts are reproducible by another developer with clear README instructions.  

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: 1-3 days

---

## ‚ö° Urgency
- [ ] Low  
- [ ] Medium  
- [‚úÖ] High  

---

## üéöÔ∏è Difficulty
- [ ] Easy  
- [‚úÖ] Moderate  
- [ ] Hard

title: [Research] Noise Robustness and Preprocessing

labels.name: state: waiting for manager
labels.description: Waiting to be assigned / Waiting for Closing

body:
## üéØ Objective
Research and prototype a lightweight preprocessing pipeline that improves the robustness of pitch and stress detection in noisy mobile recordings. The goal is a small, practical set of noise-handling techniques (VAD, denoising, trimming, normalization, augmentation) with a PoC (Proof of Concept) and measurable improvements against a baseline.

---

## üìù Description
Mobile recordings are frequently degraded by background noise: street, fan, cafe, reverb, and inconsistent levels. This spike evaluates practical preprocessing steps and tools that make our stress/intonation detectors reliable in everyday use.

Key goals:

- Define a compact preprocessing pipeline that can run on-device or in a low-latency server.

- Implement a PoC demonstrating improved pitch/stress detection under common noise conditions.

- Guide thresholds/quality checks (SNR, voice activity, clipping) and recommendations for fallback UX (ask user to re-record, show a noise warning).

Candidate building blocks to evaluate:

-Voice Activity Detection (VAD) to trim silent segments and focus processing.

-Lightweight denoising: spectral gating, Wiener filtering, or compact neural denoisers (e.g., RNNoise/WebRTC noise suppression).

-Simple normalization: RMS or peak normalization to a target amplitude, with clipping checks.

-SNR estimation and quality thresholds: compute an SNR-like metric to decide if audio is usable.

-Data augmentation for training and evaluation: mix clean recordings with common noise samples at multiple SNRs.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
  - A documented preprocessing pipeline (VAD ‚Üí denoise ‚Üí trim ‚Üí normalize ‚Üí quality check) with rationale for each step.

 - PoC implementation(s): at least one on-device-friendly approach (e.g., WebRTC, RNNoise, or spectral gating) and one server-side option (if applicable). Code samples and run instructions included.

 - Benchmark report showing improvements vs baseline on a test set. The report must show results for clean and noisy sets (SNRs: clean, +10 dB, 0 dB, -5 dB).

 - Data augmentation recipe + scripts for producing noisy test sets (mixing noises at controlled SNRs).

 - Quality gating rules (SNR threshold, % voiced frames, clipping detection) and suggested frontend messages/actions.

 - Integration notes: how to call the pipeline from Flutter (native plugin or upload flow).

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
 Test data: start with a pilot dataset ~200 utterances across many speakers. Include noisy versions by mixing in several noise types (street, cafe, fan, TV).

Experiments:

- Baseline ‚Äî no preprocessing; run existing F0/stress detector and record metrics.

- VAD + Trim ‚Äî remove silence and short non-voice segments; evaluate.

- Spectral gating / Wiener ‚Äî apply classic denoising; evaluate.

- Compact neural denoiser ‚Äî test RNNoise or a similarly lightweight model (on-device or server) and evaluate.

- Full pipeline ‚Äî VAD + denoise + normalize + quality gating.

Metrics to record:

- Stress placement accuracy (primary): percent correct stressed syllable.

- Intonation classification accuracy (rising/falling/flat).

- Voicing detection rate / valid frames % (frames where pitch was estimated).

- False rejection rate of good samples by quality gate.

- Latency: median and 95th percentile end-to-end (preproc + detector) on (a) dev laptop, (b) representative Android device.

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time:  1-5 days 

---

- [ ] Medium  
- [‚úÖ] High

title: [Research] Real-Time vs. Post-Recording Feedback
body:
## üéØ Objective
Research whether our AI Pronunciation Coach should provide real-time pronunciation feedback (while the learner is speaking) or post-recording feedback (after finishing a word/sentence).
---

## üìù Description
Different systems approach pronunciation feedback differently:
- Real-time feedback can help learners adjust on the fly but may introduce latency and technical complexity.
- Post-recording feedback is simpler to implement, allows detailed analysis (phoneme-level, intonation, clarity), but feels less immediate.

This research will:
- Explore what existing tools (e.g., Elsa Speak, Speechling, Duolingo) do.
- Identify whether Whisper, Vosk, or Kaldi/MFA can realistically support real-time scoring.
- Compare usability trade-offs for learners.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Document differences between real-time vs. post-recording feedback.
- [ ] Provide at least 2 examples of how existing apps handle it.
- [ ] Evaluate feasibility of real-time feedback with our current tools (Whisper, Vosk, Kaldi/MFA).
- [ ] Recommendation on whether our prototype should aim for real-time or post-recording feedback.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
- Check Whisper/Vosk documentation for streaming/real-time capabilities.
- Test whether Whisper latency is acceptable for short sentences/words.
- Compare output speed vs. accuracy in small trials.
- Share findings with the team for design decision.

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: _1‚Äì2 days_

title: [Research] Design the secure login pipeline
body:
## üéØ Objective
Implementing a secure login pipeline using the Supabase Authentication, the JWT tokens and multi factor authentication all integrated into a custom AppUser class in Dart for profile management.

---

## üìù Description
We need a clear and effective authentication flow design that uses supabase auth to handle the sign-up/sign-in with the ability to issue the JWT tokens to the backend. It should sync authentication data (id, email) with a feature supabase contains called Profile tables containing additional information (username, full_name, avatar_url, role, mfa_enabled, last_login). Then it all gets merged with the AppUser class that Dart utilizes so a single model can be used in the application. It should also validate the tokens on the backend before granting access and is able to keep sessions alive until the user logs out or the tokens do not match.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
List the conditions that must be met for this issue to be considered complete.  
- [ ] Visual diagram that shows the flow from login -> JWT token -> MFA -> profile merge -> AppUser creation
- [ ] A defined user data model using AppUser that combines authentication and profile data.
- [ ] Backend verification process is clear as well.  

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
How will this be tested?  
- The secure login should meet the best practices in terms of security and should handle mfa, tokens and data effectively.
- Login flow should be simple and intuitive for the user without any unecessary complications
- AppUser and the profiles table should support future growth with different features.

title: [Research] On-Device Pitch Extraction and Normalization
body:
üéØ Objective
Research and prototype a robust, low-cost method to extract fundamental frequency (F0) on mobile devices and normalize it per-speaker so pitch features can be compared across voices.

---

üìù Description
We need research to pick an F0 extraction library/algorithm (e.g., autocorrelation, YIN, or available mobile libraries), measure reliability across typical phone microphones, and implement pitch normalization (log F0). Deliver a tiny PoC that extracts F0 from short recordings and outputs a normalized pitch trace. Note links to integration into Flutter (native plugin or pure-Dart).

Why: intonation detection relies on good F0. Without reliable F0, rising/falling decisions will fail or be biased by speaker pitch range.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
 - Short comparison (3 methods) showing success rate and typical errors on 30 test recordings (male/female/child).
 
 - PoC script / native plugin demo that records audio and returns F0 contour (CSV or JSON).
  
 - Normalization strategy documented (e.g., semitone conversion + z-score) with rationale.
 
 - Integration notes (how to call from Flutter; example API).

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
-Collect 30‚Äì50 short utterances (varied speakers).

-Run each extractor, compute error vs hand-checked pitch at 10 sample points per file.

-Evaluate robustness in quiet vs noisy snippets (add background noise). 

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: 1-5 days

title: [Research] Visual Design: Login Screen Color Palette & Base Component Aesthetics
body:
## üéØ Objective
To research, design, and propose the foundational building blocks for the Login screen. This includes defining the core UI components (buttons, inputs, form container) as well as selecting an accessible and visually appealing color palette that aligns with usability and branding goals.

---

## üìù Description
The research and design process will focus on two main areas: UI components and visual styles.

- **Components**: Identify and outline the necessary base components for the login screen, such as:

         1. PrimaryButton (main CTA, e.g., "Login")

         2. SecondaryButton (optional, e.g., "Sign up")

         3. TextInput (username, email, password)

         4. Form container card (optional, depending on layout)

         5. Error/Helper text (for form validation feedback)

- **Styles:** Propose a coherent design style by selecting:

         1. Color palette (primary, secondary, background, accent colors)

         2. Typography for titles, labels, and inputs

         3. Accessibility guidelines for contrasts and readability

_This research will also include reviewing existing apps (Duolingo, Kahoot, Notion, etc.) to benchmark best practices in login UI design._

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] A document with at least 1 proposed color palette (with HEX codes) and a short justification of why it was chosen.

- [ ] A sketch or low-fidelity design showing a button and a text input styled with the proposed colors and typography.

- [ ] A list of all required base components for the login screen.

- [ ] Clear indication that the palette and components are accessible (contrast ratio verified).

---

## üß™ Testing Plan

- Check color contrast ratios to ensure accessibility for text and interactive elements.

- Share proposed designs with the team for feedback on aesthetics, readability, and user trust.

- Cross-check the proposed base components with the login screen‚Äôs functional requirements to confirm completeness.

- Confirm the proposed components are feasible to implement in code without requiring overly complex or unconventional solutions.

---

Estimated completion time:  1-2 days

title: [Research] <Orthographic English dictionary compatibility and setup with MFA>
body:
# üéØ Objective

To research and document how orthographic (word based) dictionaries in English can be integrated into the Montreal Forced Aligner (MFA). The focus is on acquiring suitable orthographic dictionaries, testing their installation, and identifying potential setup or compatibility issues.
---
# üìù Description

MFA requires dictionaries to map written words to phonetic forms. While phonetic dictionaries are commonly used, orthographic dictionaries may also play a role in preprocessing and alignment.

This issue will:

 - Identify what types of orthographic dictionaries MFA supports.

 - Document format requirements and compatibility considerations.

 - Test the installation of at least one English orthographic dictionary in MFA.

 - Record any problems during setup or usage.
---
# ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria

  - Provide clear documentation on how to install/load English orthographic dictionaries in MFA.

  - Document at least two English orthographic dictionaries that are compatible.

  - Report common challenges and propose solutions.
---
# üß™ Testing Plan

Review MFA documentation and forums for details on orthographic dictionary usage.

Document potential problems (installation, encoding, mismatches).

Compare multiple English orthographic dictionaries and note compatibility issues.

title: [Research] Goodness of Pronunciation (GOP) for Phoneme-Level Pronunciation Scoring
body:
## üéØ Objective
Research how **Goodness of Pronunciation (GOP)** scoring can be applied for evaluating learner speech in our AI Pronunciation Coach.
---

## üìù Description
To provide more detailed pronunciation feedback, we need to explore **GOP (Goodness of Pronunciation)** methods. GOP is widely used in computer-assisted pronunciation training (CAPT) to measure how closely a learner‚Äôs phoneme matches a native speaker‚Äôs pronunciation.

This research will focus on:
- Understanding how GOP is calculated (phoneme likelihood scores from acoustic models such as Kaldi).
- Identifying existing open-source implementations (e.g., Kaldi-based GOP tools, PyTorch re-implementations).
- Reviewing whether GOP supports both **English and Spanish** effectively.
- Evaluating if GOP can integrate with our chosen STT model (e.g., Whisper, Vosk).

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Clear explanation of GOP and how it works for pronunciation evaluation.
- [ ] At least 2 references to open-source tools, research papers, or projects that use GOP.
- [ ] Pros/cons of using GOP in our app (accuracy, complexity, performance).
- [ ] Recommendation on whether to test GOP in the prototype.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
- Review at least 2 sources (GitHub repos, papers, or blog posts) that implement GOP.
- Check if tools support English and Spanish.
- Share findings with team for discussion on feasibility.

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated completion time: _1‚Äì2 days_  

---

üéØ Objective

Research and design Regional/Cultural Name Pronunciation Packs (initial focus: Hispanic and English names), to understand how to source name lists, generate audio (TTS vs. recordings), and deliver a practice UX flow.

‚∏ª

üìù Description

Name pronunciation is crucially important when learning pronunciation in a different language, and in some cases, knowing how to pronounce a name correctly will open more doors for you than most words.

This task involves gathering research and producing a design blueprint for implementing ‚ÄúName Pronunciation Packs‚Äù by culture or region. Specifically, start with Hispanic and English name packs, and plan for future expansion (e.g., Indian, Chinese, European names). The deliverable will be a PDF that includes:
	‚Ä¢	Sources of reliable name lists by region
	‚Ä¢	Comparison of audio generation strategies (TTS vs. crowdsourced recordings)
	‚Ä¢	A sample pack (20 names each) for Hispanic and English names (with IPA and placeholder audio)
	‚Ä¢	Sample UX flow for how users access and practice these packs

‚∏ª

‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
	‚Ä¢	Identified at least reliable data sources for Hispanic names and 3 for English names
	‚Ä¢	Compare pros/cons of TTS vs. native recordings for pronunciation audio

	‚Ä¢	Deliver a workflow illustrating how users select and practice name packs

‚∏ª

üß™ Testing Plan

title: [Research] Phoneme-by-Phoneme Playback for Pronunciation Practice
body:
## Objective
Implement a feature that breaks down a word into its phoneme components (IPA) and provides phoneme-by-phoneme playback so learners can focus on difficult sounds before practicing full words.

üìù Description
We want to allow users to hear and practice each phoneme within a word. For example, the word ‚Äúcat‚Äù would be broken into /k/ /√¶/ /t/, and the system would play each sound separately via TTS. This will scaffold learning by giving users smaller, easier chunks to practice.

Phoneme Extraction

- Convert input word into IPA phonemes.

- Split phonemes into an ordered sequence.

Playback Functionality

- Enable phoneme-by-phoneme playback using TTS.

- Allow users to repeat each phoneme individually.

Feedback Integration

- Compare user‚Äôs attempt at a single phoneme to the target phoneme.

- Provide micro-feedback before moving on to the full word.

‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria

- Word is automatically converted into its phoneme sequence (IPA).

- Each phoneme can be played individually via TTS.

- User can attempt phoneme pronunciation and receive feedback.

- Feature integrates smoothly into the overall pronunciation coach flow.

üß™ Testing Plan

- Collect a small dataset of phonemes (e.g., from CMU Pronouncing Dictionary).

- Test playback accuracy for different phonemes.

- Test phoneme feedback with varying user speech quality.

- Ensure low latency between phoneme playback and user retry.

‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated research & prototype duration: 2‚Äì4 days

## üéØ Objective
## Find a specific way on how to implement AI in providing a response to the user and verify if it can be implemented in other areas of the project. 


---

## üìù Description
AI will be implemented in the responses to a user's pronunciation. We need to find the most efficient and useful way to use AI and how to make sure the AI makes the least amount of errors as possible. Investigating how other apps/websites make use of AI might help us get a better understanding on how to do these things. Some apps/websites also have a "AI helper" where you may ask the AI whatever question you may have. Researching this might also help us be more efficient.

title: [Research] <User Adaptive Dashboard and Growth Visual>
body:
## üéØ Objective
Explore best practices for adaptive dashboards in pronunciation learning apps. Focusing on how dashboards can personalize what they show depending on the user‚Äôs level of progress and recent performance.

---

## üìù Description
Our AI pronunciation coach needs a dashboard that doesn‚Äôt just display static progress but adapts as the learner grows. This research task will explore adaptive dashboard patterns, emphasizing personalization and progressive complexity. The research should focus on:

Adaptive Dashboard Structures
Beginner: simple progress bar, daily target, motivational visuals, simplified visuals and avatars.
Intermediate: error tracking, accuracy breakdowns, ‚ÄúTop 3 Mistakes‚Äù list.
Advanced: detailed phoneme mastery , weekly/monthly trend graphs, next-best practice recommendation.

Adaptive Principles
Tiered Information: show more detail as skill improves.
Progressive Reveal: unlock advanced visualizations after consistent use.
Personalized Recommendations: dashboard highlights the next-best practice item based on recent errors and performance.

Inspirations from Existing Apps
Educational apps: adaptive lesson progression and ‚Äúnext recommended task‚Äù systems.
Fitness platforms: simplified dashboards for casual users vs. detailed analytics for advanced users.
Mobile games: progressive reveal of features, tiered feedback, and reward-based engagement.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- Document 3+ examples of adaptive dashboards.
- Provide 3+ preliminary dashboard layouts with descriptions of what each shows.
- Identify at least 2 adaptive principles (e.g., progressive reveal, tiered info) with evidence from real apps.
- Documentation detailing previously mentioned points.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
How will this be tested?  
- Validate findings with examples from educational, fitness, and mobile gaming platforms.
- Compare effectiveness of simple vs. complex dashboards for different user types.
- Check accessibility and clarity of proposed dashboard layouts. 

---

Estimated completion time: 1 to 3 days.

title: [Research] <Implementation of Login & Home Page>
body:
## üéØ Objective
Research and define the optimal Flutter-based approach for building our initial milestone: a functional Login Page with input validation and a simple, aesthetically pleasing Home Page. This research will ensure we use the most efficient widgets, state management techniques, and project structure from the start.

---

## üìù Description
This research task is critical for the frontend team's work in Weeks 1 and 2. We need to investigate and decide on the following for the Login and Home pages using Flutter:
1.  **Login Page Implementation:**
    *   Best widgets for building forms: `TextFormField` vs. `TextField` with custom `InputDecoration`.
    *   Techniques for robust form validation (using the `validator` property and a `GlobalKey<FormState>`).
    *   How to handle state for the form inputs (e.g., using `TextEditingController` or a state management solution).
    *   Methods to provide user feedback (e.g., `SnackBar` for errors, navigating to Home on success).

2.  **State Management (Basic):**
    *   Research the simplest approach for our current needs (e.g., `setState` within a single widget).
    *   Evaluate if a more scalable solution like `Provider` or `Bloc` is necessary for this initial milestone or if it can be added later.

3.  **Home Page Design & Structure:**
    *   Research basic layout widgets (`Scaffold`, `AppBar`, `Container`, `Column`, `Row`) to create a simple structure.
    *   Investigate how to create a navigation flow (e.g., `Navigator.pushReplacement` to go from Login to Home).
    *   Look into pre-designed `Card` widgets or list tiles to display content neatly.

4.  **Styling & Theming:**
    *   Research how to use the `ThemeData` class to define a consistent color scheme and typography for the app.
    *   Evaluate the use of external packages like `flutter_bloc` for state management or `google_fonts` for typography, if needed.


---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] A documented guide on building a validated login form in Flutter.
- [ ] A recommended approach for handling form state and navigation.
- [ ] A code snippet for a basic Login Page and Home Page skeleton.
- [ ] A decided-upon project structure for our screens and widgets.
- [ ] A list of relevant external packages (with version numbers) to add to `pubspec.yaml`
 

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
- The findings will be tested by implementing the Login and Home pages according to the research.
- We will verify that the input boxes capture data and validate correctly.
- We will test the navigation between the Login and Home pages.
- We will ensure the UI is visually consistent and runs on both Android and iOS emulators.


---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated research duration: **1 day**
*(This research is needed immediately to start Week 1 development effectively)*


---

title: [Research] <Stress Placement and Basic Word Intonation>
body:
## üéØ Objective
Research a simple, prototype ready method to detect stress placement and basic word level intonation (rising vs. falling) for short words and phrases.

---

## üìù Description
This task will investigate methods for giving learners real-time feedback on stress placement and intonation in short utterances (single words or short phrases).

User flow (how learners will use it):
     The learner records a short word or phrase.
     The system analyzes the recording and highlights which syllable was stressed.
     The system shows whether the overall intonation went up or down.
     The learner sees corrections and can retry immediately.

Expected outputs:
     1. A recommended approach (with rationale on accuracy, speed, and ease of integration).
     2. A small proof-of-concept that demonstrates stress and intonation detection on ~200 recordings.
     3. A simple API/response format so the frontend can display feedback.
     4. A short note on risks, privacy/on-device feasibility, and test plan.

Techniques/approaches:
     Using speech alignment + pitch/energy patterns to detect stressed syllables.
     Using existing speech models that include prosody information.
     Using pitch contour analysis to decide rising vs falling intonation.
     Combining approaches for better accuracy.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria 
- [ ] A short risk and mitigation list (examples such as noisy recordings, mis-segmentation) with simple remedies. 
- [ ] A comparison of the candidate approaches: setup time, expected reliability, latency, and integration effort.  
- [ ] A brief privacy and deployment note indicating if the chosen approach is feasible on-device. 

---

## üß™ Testing Plan

title: # [Research] Daily Challenge Score & Streak Systems for Pronunciation Apps

labels.name: task: development
labels.description: Dev work  Includes: code, design, testing, docs

body:
## üéØ Objective

Research best practices for implementing a **Daily Challenge system** in pronunciation learning apps, focusing on **score accumulation, streak mechanics, and bonus rewards** that motivate users to practice consistently.

---

## üìù Description

This task explores how a **scoring and streak-based challenge system** can be designed for our AI pronunciation coach. The idea is to:

1. **Daily Challenge Mechanics**

   * A new pronunciation challenge is available every 24 hours.
   * Completing it gives a **base score** (e.g., 100 points).

2. **Streak & Reset System**

   * Users earn a **streak** by completing challenges on consecutive days.
   * Streak resets if the user misses a day.

3. **Bonus Challenges**

   * On specific days (e.g., every 5th day), users are offered a **bonus challenge** that is harder but worth **double points**.

4. **Motivation & Retention**

   * Research UI/UX patterns that show streak progression.
   * Look at how apps use **points + streaks** to maximize daily retention.

Deliverable: A document (`docs/daily-challenge-score-research.md`) summarizing score systems, streak mechanics, and bonus challenges from language-learning apps and gamified platforms.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria

* [ ] Document at least 3 examples of apps using score + streak systems.
* [ ] Research how daily reset mechanics are communicated to users.
* [ ] Identify at least 2 methods for bonus/multiplier challenges.
* [ ] Provide recommendations on how to adapt these ideas for **pronunciation-specific challenges**.

---

## üß™ Testing Plan

* Validate findings with examples (Duolingo streaks, Memrise points, fitness app streaks, etc.).
* Check how scoring affects long-term engagement (credible sources).
* Ensure recommendations align with pronunciation practice (not just generic quiz mechanics).

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe

Estimated completion time: **2‚Äì3 days** 

---

* [ ] High

## üéØ Objective
Researching and evaluating different approaches to creating a secure login client that is able to send credentials safely to the backend for verifying the identity of the user logging in.

---

## üìù Description
The application for our pronunciation coach needs to have a front-end that is able to effectively communicate with the back-end to collect credentials and send them without compromising the safety of the user in common security attacks and/or risks.

Tasks:
-Identify possible APIs that specialize on authentication and logins.

-Compare the APIs with clear goals needed to be met:
   1. The API must have good synergy with Flutter/Dart and is able to use its features efficiently.
   2. Able to communicate effectively with the backend and send the credentials securely.
   3. One that potentially offers stronger optional security features (biometric authentication and two factor)

-Decide on 1 API that could be used to implement into the application.

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria
List the conditions that must be met for this issue to be considered complete.  
- [x] Documenting the chosen API detailing why it was chosen and why it was the best option of the ones researched.
- [x] The application has access to a library of authentication features.
- [x] Installation guide and compability with pre existing libraries must be documented

---

## üß™ Testing Plan

- Verify with the team responsible of login in the front-end and the team responsible of login-in the back end that this is a viable option.

- Testing that the application's frontend can efficiently communicate to the backend without security leaks.

title: [Research] Methods for Real-Time Pronunciation Feedback

labels.name: task: development
labels.description: Dev work  Includes: code, design, testing, docs

body:
## üéØ Objective
Explore methods to provide **real-time pronunciation feedback** in a Results/Feedback screen by comparing user speech with sample consonant and vowel sounds by converting sounds into graphs and analyzing the similarity between them.

---

## üìù Description
We need to figure out if it's possible to turn speech samples from English consonants and vowels as well as user speech into a format that we can compare to display the pronunciation feedback.

1. **Graph Construction**  
   - Convert sample and user speech as graphs.  

2. **Mathematical Comparison**  
   - Compare sample and user speech graphs. 

3. **Feedback Generation**  
   - Translate similarity scores into a **confidence percentage (0 to 100%)**.  
   - Define feedback as: ‚úÖ Correct, üîÑ Needs Improvement.  

---

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria  
- [x] System generates graphs for both sample and user audio.   
- [x] Mathematical comparison produces a similarity/confidence score (0 to 100%).   
- [x] Graph generation and comparison runs good enough to use in real-time. 

---

## üß™ Testing Plan
- Collect a dataset of English consonants and vowels (sample + user).   
- Test in real-time to make sure feedback is displayed with minimal (or acceptable) latency.
- Include cases such as background noise or different accents.

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Timeframe
Estimated research duration: **2 to 3 days**
